  • Log in to your hosting account's control panel (e.g., cPanel).

b. Find the WordPress Installer

  • Look for WordPress or Softaculous Apps Installer.

c. Install WordPress

  1. Click on WordPress Installer

  2. Fill in the Installation Details:

    • Choose Protocol: https:// (if SSL is available) or http://.
    • Choose Domain: tailsadoption.org.
    • In Directory: Leave blank to install at the root.
    • Site Name: Tails Adoption
    • Site Description: A place to adopt and rehome pets.
    • Admin Username: Create a new username (avoid using "admin").
    • Admin Password: Create a strong password.
    • Admin Email: Your email address.

  3. Advanced Options (Optional):

    • Database Name: Leave default or customize.
    • Table Prefix: Leave default (wp_) or customize.

  4. Select Plugins (Optional):

    • You can skip this for now.

  5. Install:

    • Click Install and wait for the process to complete.

Step 5: Export Content from WordPress.com

a. Log in to WordPress.com

  • Go to WordPress.com and log in.

b. Navigate to the Export Tool

  1. Go to My Site > Tools > Export.
  2. Under Export Content, click Export All.

c. Download the Export File

  • You'll receive a .xml file containing your site's content.

Step 6: Import Content to Your Self-Hosted Site

a. Log in to Your New WordPress Dashboard

  • Access your site at https://tailsadoption.org/wp-admin/.

b. Install the WordPress Importer

  1. Go to Tools > Import.
  2. Under WordPress, click Install Now.

c. Import Content

  1. Click Run Importer.
  2. Upload the Export File:
    • Click Choose File and select the .xml file you downloaded.
    • Click Upload file and import.
  3. Assign Authors:
    • Assign posts to an existing user or create a new one.
  4. Import Attachments:
    • Check Download and import file attachments.
  5. Click Submit.

Step 7: Set Up Your Theme and Child Theme

a. Choose and Install a Theme

Option 1: Use a Free Theme

  • Recommended Themes:
    • Astra
    • OceanWP
    • Neve

  1. Install the Parent Theme:

    • Go to Appearance > Themes > Add New.
    • Search for Astra.
    • Click Install and then Activate.

b. Create a Child Theme

Method 1: Manually Create a Child Theme

  1. Create a Child Theme Folder

    • On your local computer, create a folder named astra-child.

  2. Create style.css

    css
    /*
 Theme Name: Tails Adoption Child Theme
 Theme URI: https://tailsadoption.org/
 Description: Child theme for Tails Adoption
 Author: Ian
 Author URI: https://tailsadoption.org/
 Template: astra
 Version: 1.0.0
*/

  3. Create functions.php

    php
    <?php
function tailsadoption_enqueue_styles() {
    $parent_style = 'astra-style';
    wp_enqueue_style( $parent_style, get_template_directory_uri() . '/style.css' );
    wp_enqueue_style( 'child-style',
        get_stylesheet_directory_uri() . '/style.css',
        array( $parent_style ),
        wp_get_theme()->get('Version')
    );
}
add_action( 'wp_enqueue_scripts', 'tailsadoption_enqueue_styles' );
?>

  4. Zip the Child Theme Folder

    • Compress astra-child into astra-child.zip.

  5. Upload and Activate the Child Theme

    • Go to Appearance > Themes > Add New > Upload Theme.
    • Upload astra-child.zip.
    • Activate the Tails Adoption Child Theme.

Method 2: Use a Plugin

  • Install Child Theme Configurator:

    1. Go to Plugins > Add New.
    2. Search for Child Theme Configurator.
    3. Install and activate the plugin.
    4. Follow the plugin instructions to create a child theme.

Step 8: Install Necessary Plugins

a. User Management

  • User Role Editor

    • Manage custom user roles and capabilities.

b. Forms

  • Contact Form 7 or WPForms

    • Create contact forms and submission forms.

c. Custom Post Types

  • Custom Post Type UI (CPT UI)

    • Create custom post types for pets.

  • Advanced Custom Fields (ACF)

    • Add custom fields to your post types.

d. Security

  • Wordfence Security

    • Protect your site from malicious attacks.

e. SEO

  • Yoast SEO

    • Optimize your site for search engines.

f. Analytics

  • Google Analytics for WordPress by MonsterInsights

    • Integrate Google Analytics.

Step 9: Implement Customizations and Code

a. Set Up Custom User Roles

Add Roles via Code

Add the following to your child theme's functions.php:

php
<?php
// Existing code...

// Add custom user roles
function add_custom_user_roles() {
    add_role( 'owner', 'Owner', array( 'read' => true ) );
    add_role( 'administrator', 'Administrator', array( 'read' => true ) );
    add_role( 'moderator', 'Moderator', array( 'read' => true ) );
}
add_action( 'init', 'add_custom_user_roles' );
?>

b. Create Custom Post Type for Pets

Add to functions.php:

php
function create_pet_post_type() {
    register_post_type( 'pet',
        array(
            'labels' => array(
                'name' => __( 'Pets' ),
                'singular_name' => __( 'Pet' )
            ),
            'public' => true,
            'has_archive' => true,
            'rewrite' => array( 'slug' => 'adopt' ),
            'supports' => array( 'title', 'editor', 'author', 'thumbnail' ),
        )
    );
}
add_action( 'init', 'create_pet_post_type' );

c. Add Custom Fields to Pet Post Type

Use Advanced Custom Fields (ACF) to add fields like:

  • Pet Name
  • Description
  • Type of Animal (Dropdown)
  • Sex (Radio Buttons)
  • Microchip Implant (Yes/No)
  • Vaccines and Surgeries (Text Area)
  • Pickup Method (Checkboxes)
  • Contact Information (Name, Email, Phone)
  • Location (City, State/Province)
  • Image Uploads (Gallery)

d. Create the "Rehome" Page Template

Create page-rehome.php in your child theme:

php
<?php
/**
 * Template Name: Rehome Page
 */

if ( ! is_user_logged_in() ) {
    wp_redirect( wp_login_url( get_permalink() ) );
    exit;
}

get_header();

// Display the pet submission form
echo do_shortcode('[contact-form-7 id="##### FORM ID #####" title="Rehome Your Pet"]');

get_footer();
?>
  • Use Contact Form 7 to create the submission form.
  • Integrate ACF fields into the form.

e. Create the "Adopt" Page Template

Create archive-pet.php in your child theme:

php
<?php
get_header(); ?>

<main>
    <h1>Available Pets for Adoption</h1>
    <?php if ( have_posts() ) : ?>
        <div class="pet-listings">
            <?php while ( have_posts() ) : the_post(); ?>
                <div class="pet-card">
                    <a href="<?php the_permalink(); ?>">
                        <?php if ( has_post_thumbnail() ) {
                            the_post_thumbnail( 'medium' );
                        } ?>
                        <h2><?php the_title(); ?></h2>
                        <p><?php echo wp_trim_words( get_the_content(), 10, '...' ); ?></p>
                    </a>
                </div>
            <?php endwhile; ?>
        </div>
    <?php else : ?>
        <p>No pets found.</p>
    <?php endif; ?>
</main>

<?php get_footer(); ?>

f. Display Pet Details

Create single-pet.php:

php
<?php
get_header();

if ( have_posts() ) : while ( have_posts() ) : the_post();
?>

<main>
    <h1><?php the_title(); ?></h1>
    <?php if ( has_post_thumbnail() ) {
        the_post_thumbnail( 'large' );
    } ?>
    <div class="pet-details">
        <?php the_content(); ?>
        <!-- Display custom fields -->
        <p><strong>Type of Animal:</strong> <?php the_field( 'type_of_animal' ); ?></p>
        <!-- Add more fields as needed -->
    </div>
    <?php if ( is_user_logged_in() ) : ?>
        <div class="contact-info">
            <h2>Contact Information</h2>
            <p><strong>Name:</strong> <?php the_field( 'your_name' ); ?></p>
            <p><strong>Email:</strong> <?php the_field( 'email_address' ); ?></p>
            <p><strong>Phone:</strong> <?php the_field( 'phone' ); ?></p>
        </div>
    <?php else : ?>
        <p>Please <a href="<?php echo wp_login_url( get_permalink() ); ?>">log in</a> to view contact information.</p>
    <?php endif; ?>
</main>

<?php
endwhile; endif;

get_footer();
?>

g. Implement Login and Registration

Custom Registration Form

Create page-register.php:

php
<?php
/**
 * Template Name: Registration Page
 */

get_header();

if ( isset( $_POST['submit'] ) ) {
    $username = sanitize_user( $_POST['username'] );
    $email = sanitize_email( $_POST['email'] );
    $password = $_POST['password'];

    // Password validation
    $errors = array();
    if ( strlen( $password ) < 8 ) {
        $errors[] = 'Password must be at least 8 characters long.';
    }
    if ( ! preg_match( '/[A-Z]/', $password ) ) {
        $errors[] = 'Password must contain at least one capital letter.';
    }
    if ( ! preg_match( '/[^A-Za-z]/', $password ) ) {
        $errors[] = 'Password must contain at least one non-letter character.';
    }

    if ( empty( $errors ) ) {
        $user_id = wp_create_user( $username, $password, $email );
        if ( ! is_wp_error( $user_id ) ) {
            echo '<p>Registration successful. Please <a href="' . wp_login_url() . '">log in</a>.</p>';
        } else {
            echo '<p>Error: ' . $user_id->get_error_message() . '</p>';
        }
    } else {
        foreach ( $errors as $error ) {
            echo '<p>' . $error . '</p>';
        }
    }
}

?>

<form method="post" action="">
    <label for="username">Username</label>
    <input type="text" name="username" id="username" required>
    <label for="email">Email</label>
    <input type="email" name="email" id="email" required>
    <label for="password">Password</label>
    <input type="password" name="password" id="password" required>
    <input type="submit" name="submit" value="Register">
</form>

<?php get_footer(); ?>

Step 10: Test and Launch Your Site

a. Thorough Testing

  • Functionality: Test all forms, user registration, login, pet submissions, and listings.
  • Responsiveness: Ensure the site looks good on desktop, tablet, and mobile devices.
  • Browser Compatibility: Test on different browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari).

b. Performance Optimization

  • Install WP Super Cache or W3 Total Cache for caching.
  • Optimize images using Smush.

c. Security Measures

  • Change the default admin username if necessary.
  • Install SSL Certificate (often provided free by hosting providers via Let's Encrypt).
  • Regularly update WordPress, themes, and plugins.

d. Backup Your Site

  • Use UpdraftPlus to schedule regular backups.

e. SEO and Analytics

  • Configure Yoast SEO settings.
  • Set up Google Analytics and connect it to your site.

f. Legal Pages

  • Create Privacy Policy and Terms of Service pages.
  • Use online generators or consult legal advice.

Additional Considerations

Email Deliverability

  • Configure SMTP for reliable email sending.

    • Install WP Mail SMTP.
    • Set up using your hosting email or a service like SendGrid.

User Privacy and Data Protection

  • Ensure compliance with regulations like GDPR if applicable.
  • Provide options for users to delete their data.

Future Scalability

  • Choose plugins and themes that are well-supported and regularly updated.
  • Plan for potential traffic increases.

Conclusion

Moving to a self-hosted WordPress site provides you with the flexibility and control to create the website you envision. While it requires more responsibility in terms of maintenance and security, the benefits are significant.

Feel free to ask if you need more detailed instructions on any of these steps or assistance with specific code implementations. I'm here to help you every step of the way!

You said:
Since wordpress is already hosting my domain, is it possible to skip steps 1-3? if yes, go ahead and rewrite these instructions with that in mind.

Thank you for your question!

Since your domain tailsadoption.org is already registered and hosted with WordPress.com, you can keep your domain registration with WordPress.com and point it to your new self-hosted WordPress site. This means you can skip the domain registration part but still need to select a hosting provider and update your DNS settings.

Here's how we'll adjust the steps:

  • Skip Step 1 (Select a Hosting Provider): We'll proceed directly to choosing and purchasing a hosting plan.
  • Adjust Step 2 (Purchase a Hosting Plan): We'll start from here.
  • Adjust Step 3 (Point Your Domain to the New Host): Since your domain is with WordPress.com, you'll update your DNS settings accordingly.

Rewritten Instructions

Step 1: Purchase a Hosting Plan

Since you're moving to a self-hosted WordPress site, you'll need to purchase a hosting plan from a reliable hosting provider.

Recommended Hosting Providers

  • SiteGround: www.siteground.com
  • Bluehost: www.bluehost.com
  • DreamHost: www.dreamhost.com
  • HostGator: www.hostgator.com

Factors to Consider:

  • Performance and Uptime
  • Customer Support
  • Ease of Use
  • Pricing and Plans
  • Security Features
  • Scalability

a. Choose a Hosting Plan

  • Shared Hosting is suitable for small to medium websites.

  • Example with SiteGround:

    1. Visit SiteGround WordPress Hosting.
    2. Choose a plan (e.g., StartUp, GrowBig, GoGeek).
    3. Click Get Plan.

b. Use Your Existing Domain

  • Since you already own tailsadoption.org, during the sign-up process:

    • SiteGround: Select I already have a Domain and enter tailsadoption.org.
    • Bluehost: Choose Use a domain you own.

c. Complete the Purchase

  • Fill in your account and payment information.
  • Review and confirm your order.

Step 2: Point Your Domain to the New Host

Since your domain is registered with WordPress.com, you'll need to update your domain's DNS settings to point to your new hosting provider.

a. Obtain Your New Host's Name Servers

  • After purchasing your hosting plan, your hosting provider will provide you with their name servers.
    • Example for SiteGround:
      • ns1.siteground.net
      • ns2.siteground.net
    • Example for Bluehost:
      • ns1.bluehost.com
      • ns2.bluehost.com

b. Update DNS Settings on WordPress.com

  1. Log in to WordPress.com

    • Go to WordPress.com and log in to your account.

  2. Navigate to Domain Management

    • Click on My Site in the top-left corner.
    • On the left-hand menu, scroll down and click on Upgrades.
    • Select Domains.
    • Click on your domain name tailsadoption.org.

  3. Access DNS Settings

    • In the domain settings, click on Name Servers and DNS.

  4. Change Name Servers

    • By default, your domain uses WordPress.com name servers.
    • Select Use custom name servers.
    • Enter the name servers provided by your new hosting provider.
      • Example:
        • Name Server 1: ns1.siteground.net
        • Name Server 2: ns2.siteground.net
    • Click Save or Update.

c. Wait for DNS Propagation

  • DNS changes can take up to 48 hours to propagate globally, but it's often faster (usually within a few hours).

Note: During this time, your website may be intermittently accessible. Plan accordingly to minimize disruption.

Step 3: Install WordPress on Your New Host

Most hosting providers offer one-click WordPress installation.

a. Access Your Hosting Account

  • Log in to your hosting account's control panel (e.g., cPanel or custom dashboard).

b. Find the WordPress Installer

  • Look for WordPress or Softaculous Apps Installer.

c. Install WordPress

  1. Click on WordPress Installer

    • This will start the installation wizard.

  2. Fill in the Installation Details:

    • Choose Protocol: https:// (if SSL is available) or http://.
    • Choose Domain: Select tailsadoption.org from the dropdown.
    • In Directory: Leave this field empty to install WordPress in the root directory.
    • Site Name: Tails Adoption
    • Site Description: A place to adopt and rehome pets.
    • Admin Username: Create a new username (avoid using "admin" for security reasons).
    • Admin Password: Create a strong password.
    • Admin Email: Your email address.

  3. Advanced Options (Optional):

    • Database Name: Leave default or customize.
    • Table Prefix: Leave default (wp_) or customize.

  4. Select Plugins (Optional):

    • You can skip this for now.

  5. Install:

    • Click Install and wait for the process to complete.

d. Secure Your Site with SSL (Optional but Recommended)

  • Many hosting providers offer free SSL certificates via Let's Encrypt.
  • Install SSL to enable https:// on your site.

Step 4: Export Content from WordPress.com

a. Log in to WordPress.com

  • Go to WordPress.com and log in.

b. Navigate to the Export Tool

  1. Go to My Site > Tools > Export.
  2. Under Export Content, click Export All.

c. Download the Export File

  • You'll receive a .xml file containing your site's content.

Step 5: Import Content to Your Self-Hosted Site

a. Log in to Your New WordPress Dashboard

  • Access your site at https://tailsadoption.org/wp-admin/.

b. Install the WordPress Importer

  1. Go to Tools > Import.
  2. Under WordPress, click Install Now.

c. Import Content

  1. Click Run Importer.

  2. Upload the Export File:

    • Click Choose File and select the .xml file you downloaded from WordPress.com.
    • Click Upload file and import.

  3. Assign Authors:

    • Assign posts to an existing user or create a new one.

  4. Import Attachments:

    • Check Download and import file attachments to bring over your media files.

  5. Click Submit.

Step 6: Set Up Your Theme and Child Theme

a. Choose and Install a Theme

Since you have full control now, you can choose a theme that supports child themes.

Option: Use a Free, Flexible Theme

  • Recommended Themes:
    • Astra
    • GeneratePress
    • OceanWP

  1. Install the Parent Theme:

    • Go to Appearance > Themes > Add New.
    • Search for Astra.
    • Click Install and then Activate.

b. Create a Child Theme

Method: Manually Create a Child Theme

  1. Create a Child Theme Folder

    • On your local computer, create a folder named astra-child.

  2. Create style.css

    css
    /*
 Theme Name: Tails Adoption Child Theme
 Theme URI: https://tailsadoption.org/
 Description: Child theme for Tails Adoption
 Author: Ian
 Author URI: https://tailsadoption.org/
 Template: astra
 Version: 1.0.0
*/

  3. Create functions.php

    php
    <?php
function tailsadoption_enqueue_styles() {
    $parent_style = 'astra-style'; // This is 'astra-style' for the Astra theme.
    wp_enqueue_style( $parent_style, get_template_directory_uri() . '/style.css' );
    wp_enqueue_style( 'child-style',
        get_stylesheet_directory_uri() . '/style.css',
        array( $parent_style ),
        wp_get_theme()->get('Version')
    );
}
add_action( 'wp_enqueue_scripts', 'tailsadoption_enqueue_styles' );
?>

  4. Zip the Child Theme Folder

    • Compress astra-child into astra-child.zip.

  5. Upload and Activate the Child Theme

    • Go to Appearance > Themes > Add New > Upload Theme.
    • Upload astra-child.zip.
    • Activate the Tails Adoption Child Theme.

Step 7: Install Necessary Plugins

a. User Management

  • User Role Editor

    • Manage custom user roles and capabilities.

b. Forms

  • Contact Form 7 or WPForms

    • Create contact forms and submission forms.

c. Custom Post Types

  • Custom Post Type UI (CPT UI)

    • Create custom post types for pets.

  • Advanced Custom Fields (ACF)

    • Add custom fields to your post types.

d. Security

  • Wordfence Security

    • Protect your site from malicious attacks.

e. SEO

  • Yoast SEO

    • Optimize your site for search engines.

f. Analytics

  • Google Analytics for WordPress by MonsterInsights

    • Integrate Google Analytics.

Step 8: Implement Customizations and Code

[This section remains largely the same as previously outlined.]

a. Set Up Custom User Roles

[Include code and instructions as previously provided.]

b. Create Custom Post Type for Pets

[Include code and instructions as previously provided.]

c. Add Custom Fields to Pet Post Type

[Use ACF to add fields.]

d. Create the "Rehome" Page Template

[Include code and instructions as previously provided.]

e. Create the "Adopt" Page Template

[Include code and instructions as previously provided.]

f. Display Pet Details

[Include code and instructions as previously provided.]

g. Implement Login and Registration

[Include code and instructions as previously provided.]

Step 9: Test and Launch Your Site

[Proceed with testing, optimization, and security measures as previously outlined.]

Additional Considerations

[Include any additional considerations as previously outlined.]

Summary

By keeping your domain registered with WordPress.com and pointing it to your new hosting provider, you can set up a self-hosted WordPress site without needing to purchase a new domain. This approach gives you full control over your website's functionality and customization options.

Key Steps:

  • Purchase a hosting plan.
  • Update your domain's DNS settings on WordPress.com to point to your new host.
  • Install WordPress on your new hosting account.
  • Export content from WordPress.com and import it to your new site.
  • Set up your theme, child theme, and necessary plugins.
  • Implement custom code and functionalities as per your requirements.
  • Thoroughly test your site before launching.

Feel free to let me know if you need further clarification on any of these steps or assistance with specific implementations. I'm here to support you throughout this process!

You said:
I'm currently on "Step 3: Install WordPress on Your New Host". My dashboard has a link to "Install & Manage WordPress". I click that, and it takes me to WordPress > Install & Manage. In "Manage installations" table, I see one row containing: domain "tailsadoption.org/", installation "WordPress", current version "6.6.2", and actions. When I click WordPress" to install new WordPress, I receive the message "Failed to install WordPress on tailsadoption.org/. There are already files belonging to a website in this folder. Review and delete them before retrying" from the site. I do not have WordPress installed on my local drive at the moment. Is this step satisfied? If not, how should I proceed?

Thank you for providing the detailed information about the issue you're encountering.

Based on the message you're receiving, it appears that WordPress is already installed on your new hosting account for tailsadoption.org. This is why you're seeing the error:

"Failed to install WordPress on tailsadoption.org/. There are already files belonging to a website in this folder. Review and delete them before retrying."

Here's how you should proceed:

1. Check if WordPress is Already Installed

Since the hosting control panel shows an existing WordPress installation, let's verify if WordPress is already set up on your new host.

a. Access Your WordPress Admin Dashboard

  • Open your web browser and navigate to:

    arduino
    https://tailsadoption.org/wp-admin/

b. Attempt to Log In

  • Username and Password:
    • Use the admin username and password you might have set during the hosting setup.
    • If you didn't set these credentials, they might have been sent to you via email by your hosting provider.
  • Forgot Password:
    • If you're unsure of the password, click on "Lost your password?" on the login page.
    • Enter the email address associated with your admin account to reset your password.

c. Verify the WordPress Installation

  • Successful Login:
    • If you can log in to the WordPress dashboard, WordPress is already installed.
    • You can proceed to the next steps (importing content, setting up themes, etc.).
  • Unable to Login:
    • If you cannot log in or the login page doesn't load, proceed to the next section.

2. Determine the State of the Existing Installation

It's possible that:

  • WordPress is partially installed but not fully set up.
  • Residual files from a previous installation attempt are present.

a. Visit Your Website

  • Go to:

    arduino
    https://tailsadoption.org/

  • Possible Outcomes:

    • WordPress Setup Page Appears: This means WordPress files are present but the installation hasn't been completed.
    • Default WordPress Site: If you see a default WordPress theme with placeholder content, WordPress is installed.
    • Error Messages or Other Content: There might be an issue with the installation.

b. Check for Installation Files via File Manager

  • Access File Manager:

    • Log in to your hosting account's control panel (e.g., cPanel).
    • Navigate to File Manager or a similar file browsing tool.

  • Locate Website Directory:

    • Find the root directory for your domain, typically named public_html or tailsadoption.org.

  • Identify WordPress Files:

    • Look for typical WordPress files and folders:
      • Folders:
        • wp-admin
        • wp-content
        • wp-includes
      • Files:
        • wp-config.php
        • index.php
        • wp-login.php

3. Decide on the Next Steps

Based on what you discover, you have a few options:

Option A: WordPress is Installed and Accessible

  • Action:
    • Proceed to Step 4: Export Content from WordPress.com and continue with the setup.
  • Benefit:
    • Saves time by using the existing installation.

Option B: WordPress Files Exist but Installation Isn't Complete

  • Action:
    • Complete the WordPress installation manually.
How to Complete the Installation:

  1. Visit the Setup Page:

    arduino
    https://tailsadoption.org/wp-admin/install.php

  2. Follow the On-Screen Instructions:

    • Choose your language.
    • Enter site details (site title, admin username, password, email).
    • Complete the installation.

Option C: Installation is Corrupted or You Want a Fresh Start

  • Action:
    • Delete existing files and perform a fresh WordPress installation.
Important: Before deleting any files, ensure there is no important data that could be lost.

4. How to Perform a Fresh WordPress Installation

If you decide to start fresh:

a. Backup Any Existing Data

  • Although it's likely there's no valuable data yet, it's a good practice to back up the existing files and databases just in case.
  • Backup Steps:
    • Use the File Manager to download all files in the website directory.
    • Export any existing databases via phpMyAdmin.

b. Delete Existing Files

  • In File Manager:
    • Navigate to the root directory (public_html or similar).
    • Select all files and folders and delete them.
  • Ensure Only the Target Directory is Affected:
    • Be careful not to delete files from other directories or domains.

c. Reinstall WordPress via Hosting Control Panel

  • Return to "Install & Manage WordPress":
    • Now that the directory is empty, the installation should proceed without errors.
  • Install WordPress:
    • Click on Install WordPress.
    • Follow Installation Steps:
      • Enter the required details such as site name, admin username, and password.
  • Confirmation:
    • After successful installation, you should receive a confirmation message.

d. Access Your New WordPress Site

  • Admin Dashboard:
    • Log in at https://tailsadoption.org/wp-admin/ using the credentials you just set.
  • Verify Installation:
    • Ensure the dashboard is accessible and functional.

5. Proceed with the Remaining Steps

Once WordPress is properly installed:

  • Import Content:
    • Move on to Step 4: Export Content from WordPress.com.
    • Follow the instructions to export your content and import it into your new site.
  • Set Up Themes and Plugins:
    • Install your chosen theme and child theme.
    • Install and configure necessary plugins.
  • Implement Customizations:
    • Proceed with implementing the code and customizations as previously outlined.

6. Additional Tips and Recommendations

a. Avoid Data Loss

  • Always back up existing files before deletion, even if you believe they aren't important.

b. Use Hosting Support Resources

  • Hosting Provider Assistance:
    • If you're unsure about deleting files or encountering issues, reach out to your hosting provider's support team.
    • They can often assist with installations and troubleshooting.

c. Ensure Secure Credentials

  • Strong Passwords:
    • Use strong, unique passwords for your admin account.
  • Admin Username:
    • Avoid using "admin" as your username for security reasons.

d. Verify DNS Propagation

  • Timing Issues:
    • If you've recently updated your DNS settings, propagation might not be complete.
    • This can affect access to your site and installation processes.
  • Check Propagation Status:
    • Use tools like WhatsMyDNS to check DNS propagation.

7. Summary

  • WordPress Appears to Be Installed:
    • Attempt to log in to the WordPress dashboard.
  • If Installation Is Incomplete:
    • Complete the installation via the setup page.
  • If Installation Needs to Be Redone:
    • Backup and delete existing files.
    • Perform a fresh installation.
  • Proceed with Site Setup:
    • Import content and customize your site as planned.

8. Need Further Assistance?

  • Let Me Know:
    • If you have any questions or need clarification on any steps.
  • Hosting Support:
    • Don't hesitate to contact your hosting provider's support for issues related to installations and file management.
  • I'm Here to Help:
    • Whether it's troubleshooting access issues or guiding you through the next steps, feel free to ask.

By addressing the existing installation, you'll be able to move forward with setting up your self-hosted WordPress site and implementing all the custom features we've planned.

You said:
ok, I have successfully completed steps 1-6. From here on, I want to move away from WordPress plugins wherever reasonably possible, only using the most necessary based on what is feasible to manage without them. based on my original instructions for the primary webpages, equip me with instructions and code to implement.

Congratulations on successfully completing steps 1-6!

Moving forward, I'll provide you with detailed instructions and code to implement your primary webpages—Home, Adopt, and Rehome—while minimizing the use of WordPress plugins. We'll leverage WordPress's core functionalities and custom code to achieve the desired features.

Overview

We'll accomplish the following tasks:

  1. Set Up Custom User Roles and Capabilities
  2. Create Custom Post Type for Pets
  3. Add Custom Fields Without Plugins
  4. Implement Custom Registration and Login
  5. Develop the "Home" Page
  6. Develop the "Rehome" Page with a Custom Submission Form
  7. Develop the "Adopt" Page to Display Pet Listings
  8. Ensure Responsive Design and Styling

Prerequisites

  • Child Theme: Ensure you have a child theme set up (as previously discussed) to safely add custom code.
  • Backup: Always back up your site before making significant changes.

1. Set Up Custom User Roles and Capabilities

We'll define custom user roles directly in your functions.php file.

a. Define Custom Roles

Add the following code to your child theme's functions.php file:

php
<?php
// Add custom user roles
function tailsadoption_add_custom_roles() {
    // Owner Role
    add_role(
        'owner',
        __( 'Owner' ),
        array(
            'read' => true,
            'edit_posts' => true,
            'delete_posts' => true,
            'manage_options' => true,
            'promote_users' => true,
            'create_users' => true,
            'delete_users' => true,
            'edit_users' => true,
            'list_users' => true,
            'remove_users' => true,
            'edit_theme_options' => true,
            'manage_categories' => true,
            'manage_roles' => true, // Custom capability
        )
    );

    // Administrator Role
    add_role(
        'administrator',
        __( 'Administrator' ),
        array(
            'read' => true,
            'edit_posts' => true,
            'delete_posts' => true,
            'manage_options' => true,
            'promote_users' => true,
            'create_users' => true,
            'delete_users' => true,
            'edit_users' => true,
            'list_users' => true,
            'remove_users' => true,
            'edit_theme_options' => true,
            'manage_categories' => true,
        )
    );

    // Moderator Role
    add_role(
        'moderator',
        __( 'Moderator' ),
        array(
            'read' => true,
            'edit_posts' => true,
            'delete_posts' => true,
            'edit_others_posts' => true,
            'delete_others_posts' => true,
            'manage_categories' => true,
            'list_users' => true,
            'edit_users' => true,
            'delete_users' => false,
        )
    );

    // Adjust User Role Capabilities
    $role = get_role( 'subscriber' );
    $role->add_cap( 'upload_files' ); // Allow users to upload images
}
add_action( 'init', 'tailsadoption_add_custom_roles' );

Note: By default, the "User" role is the WordPress "Subscriber" role. We're adding the upload_files capability to allow users to upload images.

b. Handle Role Assignments

Since WordPress handles user roles upon registration, we'll ensure that new users are assigned the "User" role (Subscriber). The "Owner" account can be your admin account.

2. Create Custom Post Type for Pets

We'll register a custom post type called "Pet" to manage pet listings.

a. Register the Custom Post Type

Add the following code to your functions.php file:

php
// Register Custom Post Type for Pets
function tailsadoption_register_pet_cpt() {
    $labels = array(
        'name' => _x( 'Pets', 'Post Type General Name' ),
        'singular_name' => _x( 'Pet', 'Post Type Singular Name' ),
        'menu_name' => __( 'Pets' ),
        'name_admin_bar' => __( 'Pet' ),
        'archives' => __( 'Pet Archives' ),
        'attributes' => __( 'Pet Attributes' ),
        'parent_item_colon' => __( 'Parent Pet:' ),
        'all_items' => __( 'All Pets' ),
        'add_new_item' => __( 'Add New Pet' ),
        'add_new' => __( 'Add New' ),
        'new_item' => __( 'New Pet' ),
        'edit_item' => __( 'Edit Pet' ),
        'update_item' => __( 'Update Pet' ),
        'view_item' => __( 'View Pet' ),
        'view_items' => __( 'View Pets' ),
        'search_items' => __( 'Search Pet' ),
    );
    $args = array(
        'label' => __( 'Pet' ),
        'description' => __( 'Pets available for adoption' ),
        'labels' => $labels,
        'supports' => array( 'title', 'editor', 'author', 'thumbnail' ),
        'hierarchical' => false,
        'public' => true,
        'show_ui' => true,
        'show_in_menu' => true,
        'menu_position' => 5,
        'menu_icon' => 'dashicons-pets',
        'show_in_admin_bar' => true,
        'show_in_nav_menus' => true,
        'can_export' => true,
        'has_archive' => true,
        'rewrite' => array( 'slug' => 'adopt' ),
        'exclude_from_search' => false,
        'publicly_queryable' => true,
        'capability_type' => 'post',
    );
    register_post_type( 'pet', $args );
}
add_action( 'init', 'tailsadoption_register_pet_cpt', 0 );

3. Add Custom Fields Without Plugins

We'll use WordPress's built-in custom fields (post meta) to store additional information about each pet.

a. Enable Custom Fields in the Editor

By default, the custom fields meta box is hidden. To enable it:

  1. Edit or add a new Pet post.
  2. In the top-right corner, click on Screen Options.
  3. Check the Custom Fields option to display the meta box.

b. Define Custom Fields

We'll manually create custom fields when submitting pet listings.

Fields to Include:

  • Pet Name (pet_name)
  • Pet Description (pet_description)
  • Type of Animal (pet_type)
  • Sex (pet_sex)
  • Microchip Implant (pet_microchip)
  • Vaccines and Surgeries (pet_vaccines)
  • Pickup Method (pet_pickup)
  • Your Name (owner_name)
  • Email Address (owner_email)
  • Phone (owner_phone)
  • City (owner_city)
  • State/Province (owner_state)
  • Upload Images (Use Featured Image and Media Gallery)

c. Handling Custom Fields in Code

When displaying pet details, we'll retrieve these custom fields using get_post_meta().

4. Implement Custom Registration and Login

We'll create custom registration and login forms without plugins.

a. Custom Registration Form

Create a new page template page-register.php in your child theme:

php
<?php
/**
 * Template Name: Registration Page
 */
get_header();

if ( is_user_logged_in() ) {
    echo '<p>You are already logged in.</p>';
} else {
    if ( $_SERVER['REQUEST_METHOD'] == 'POST' ) {
        $username = sanitize_user( $_POST['username'] );
        $email = sanitize_email( $_POST['email'] );
        $password = $_POST['password'];

        // Password validation
        $errors = array();
        if ( strlen( $password ) < 8 ) {
            $errors[] = 'Password must be at least 8 characters long.';
        }
        if ( ! preg_match( '/[A-Z]/', $password ) ) {
            $errors[] = 'Password must contain at least one capital letter.';
        }
        if ( ! preg_match( '/[^A-Za-z]/', $password ) ) {
            $errors[] = 'Password must contain at least one non-letter character.';
        }

        if ( empty( $errors ) ) {
            $user_id = wp_create_user( $username, $password, $email );
            if ( ! is_wp_error( $user_id ) ) {
                echo '<p>Registration successful. Please <a href="' . wp_login_url() . '">log in</a>.</p>';
            } else {
                echo '<p>Error: ' . $user_id->get_error_message() . '</p>';
            }
        } else {
            foreach ( $errors as $error ) {
                echo '<p style="color:red;">' . $error . '</p>';
            }
        }
    }
    ?>

    <form method="post" action="" style="max-width: 400px; margin: auto;">
        <h2>Sign Up</h2>
        <label for="username">Username</label>
        <input type="text" name="username" id="username" required style="width: 100%; padding: 8px;">
        <label for="email">Email</label>
        <input type="email" name="email" id="email" required style="width: 100%; padding: 8px;">
        <label for="password">Password</label>
        <input type="password" name="password" id="password" required style="width: 100%; padding: 8px;">
        <input type="submit" value="Register" style="margin-top: 10px; padding: 10px; width: 100%;">
    </form>

    <?php
}
get_footer();
?>

b. Custom Login Form

You can use the default WordPress login or create a custom modal login form as previously described.

Add the following to your header or create a custom template part:

html
<!-- Login Modal -->
<div id="login-modal" style="display:none;">
    <!-- Modal content similar to previous implementation -->
</div>

Add JavaScript to handle the modal display.

5. Develop the "Home" Page

Create a custom page template page-home.php in your child theme:

php
<?php
/**
 * Template Name: Home Page
 */
get_header();
?>

<main>
    <!-- Hero Section -->
    <section id="hero" style="background-color: #FFD966; padding: 60px 20px; text-align: center;">
        <h1>Welcome to Tails Adoption</h1>
        <p>Your new best friend is waiting for you!</p>
        <a href="/adopt" style="background-color: #5A9BD5; color: #fff; padding: 15px 30px; text-decoration: none; border-radius: 5px;">Find a Pet</a>
    </section>

    <!-- Main Sections -->
    <section id="main-sections" style="display: flex; flex-wrap: wrap; justify-content: center; margin: 40px 0;">
        <!-- Sections for Adopt, Rehome, About Us -->
        <!-- Similar to previous implementation, with placeholders -->
    </section>

    <!-- Contact Us Section -->
    <section id="contact-us" style="background-color: #E4E4E4; padding: 40px 20px;">
        <h2>Contact Us</h2>
        <p>Email: tailsadoptionhelp@gmail.com</p>
        <p>Phone: ##### INSERT PHONE NUMBER HERE #####</p>
        <form id="contact-form" method="post" action="" style="max-width: 600px; margin: auto;">
            <label for="contact-name">Name</label>
            <input type="text" name="contact-name" id="contact-name" required style="width: 100%; padding: 10px;">
            <label for="contact-email">Email</label>
            <input type="email" name="contact-email" id="contact-email" required style="width: 100%; padding: 10px;">
            <label for="contact-message">Message</label>
            <textarea name="contact-message" id="contact-message" required style="width: 100%; padding: 10px; height: 150px;"></textarea>
            <input type="submit" value="Submit" style="background-color: #5A9BD5; color: #fff; padding: 15px 30px; border: none; cursor: pointer; border-radius: 5px; margin-top: 10px;">
        </form>
    </section>
</main>

<?php
// Handle Contact Form Submission
if ( $_SERVER['REQUEST_METHOD'] == 'POST' && isset( $_POST['contact-name'] ) ) {
    $name = sanitize_text_field( $_POST['contact-name'] );
    $email = sanitize_email( $_POST['contact-email'] );
    $message = sanitize_textarea_field( $_POST['contact-message'] );

    $to = 'tailsadoptionhelp@gmail.com';
    $subject = 'New Contact Form Submission';
    $body = "Name: $name\nEmail: $email\nMessage:\n$message";
    $headers = array( 'Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8' );

    wp_mail( $to, $subject, $body, $headers );

    echo '<p style="text-align:center; color: green;">Thank you for your message. We will get back to you soon!</p>';
}
get_footer();
?>

6. Develop the "Rehome" Page with a Custom Submission Form

Create a custom page template page-rehome.php:

php
<?php
/**
 * Template Name: Rehome Page
 */
get_header();

if ( ! is_user_logged_in() ) {
    echo '<p>Please <a href="' . wp_login_url( get_permalink() ) . '">log in</a> to submit a pet for adoption.</p>';
} else {
    if ( $_SERVER['REQUEST_METHOD'] == 'POST' && isset( $_POST['pet_submission'] ) ) {
        // Process form submission
        $current_user = wp_get_current_user();
        $post_data = array(
            'post_title'   => sanitize_text_field( $_POST['post_title'] ),
            'post_content' => sanitize_textarea_field( $_POST['pet_description'] ),
            'post_status'  => 'publish',
            'post_author'  => $current_user->ID,
            'post_type'    => 'pet',
        );

        // Insert the pet post
        $post_id = wp_insert_post( $post_data );

        if ( $post_id ) {
            // Save custom fields
            update_post_meta( $post_id, 'pet_name', sanitize_text_field( $_POST['pet_name'] ) );
            update_post_meta( $post_id, 'pet_type', sanitize_text_field( $_POST['pet_type'] ) );
            update_post_meta( $post_id, 'pet_sex', sanitize_text_field( $_POST['pet_sex'] ) );
            update_post_meta( $post_id, 'pet_microchip', sanitize_text_field( $_POST['pet_microchip'] ) );
            update_post_meta( $post_id, 'pet_vaccines', sanitize_textarea_field( $_POST['pet_vaccines'] ) );
            update_post_meta( $post_id, 'pet_pickup', sanitize_text_field( $_POST['pet_pickup'] ) );
            update_post_meta( $post_id, 'owner_name', sanitize_text_field( $_POST['owner_name'] ) );
            update_post_meta( $post_id, 'owner_email', sanitize_email( $_POST['owner_email'] ) );
            update_post_meta( $post_id, 'owner_phone', sanitize_text_field( $_POST['owner_phone'] ) );
            update_post_meta( $post_id, 'owner_city', sanitize_text_field( $_POST['owner_city'] ) );
            update_post_meta( $post_id, 'owner_state', sanitize_text_field( $_POST['owner_state'] ) );

            // Handle image uploads
            if ( ! empty( $_FILES['pet_images'] ) ) {
                $attachment_ids = array();
                $files = $_FILES['pet_images'];
                foreach ( $files['name'] as $key => $value ) {
                    if ( $files['name'][ $key ] ) {
                        $file = array(
                            'name'     => $files['name'][ $key ],
                            'type'     => $files['type'][ $key ],
                            'tmp_name' => $files['tmp_name'][ $key ],
                            'error'    => $files['error'][ $key ],
                            'size'     => $files['size'][ $key ],
                        );
                        $_FILES = array( 'upload_file' => $file );
                        $attachment_id = media_handle_upload( 'upload_file', $post_id );
                        if ( ! is_wp_error( $attachment_id ) ) {
                            $attachment_ids[] = $attachment_id;
                        }
                    }
                }
                if ( ! empty( $attachment_ids ) ) {
                    // Save attachment IDs as post meta
                    update_post_meta( $post_id, 'pet_images', $attachment_ids );
                }
            }

            echo '<p>Your pet has been submitted successfully!</p>';
        } else {
            echo '<p>There was an error submitting your pet. Please try again.</p>';
        }
    } else {
        // Display the submission form
        ?>
        <form method="post" action="" enctype="multipart/form-data" style="max-width: 600px; margin: auto;">
            <h2>Rehome Your Pet</h2>
            <label for="post_title">Post Title</label>
            <input type="text" name="post_title" id="post_title" required style="width: 100%; padding: 8px;">
            <label for="pet_name">Pet Name</label>
            <input type="text" name="pet_name" id="pet_name" required style="width: 100%; padding: 8px;">
            <label for="pet_description">Pet Description</label>
            <textarea name="pet_description" id="pet_description" required style="width: 100%; padding: 8px;"></textarea>
            <label for="pet_type">Type of Animal</label>
            <select name="pet_type" id="pet_type" required style="width: 100%; padding: 8px;">
                <option value="Dog">Dog</option>
                <option value="Cat">Cat</option>
                <option value="Bird">Bird</option>
                <option value="Reptile">Reptile</option>
                <option value="Rodent">Rodent</option>
                <option value="Livestock">Livestock</option>
                <option value="Other">Other</option>
            </select>
            <label for="pet_sex">Sex</label>
            <select name="pet_sex" id="pet_sex" required style="width: 100%; padding: 8px;">
                <option value="Male">Male</option>
                <option value="Female">Female</option>
            </select>
            <label for="pet_microchip">Microchip Implant</label>
            <select name="pet_microchip" id="pet_microchip" required style="width: 100%; padding: 8px;">
                <option value="Yes">Yes</option>
                <option value="No">No</option>
            </select>
            <label for="pet_vaccines">List all vaccines and surgeries</label>
            <textarea name="pet_vaccines" id="pet_vaccines" required style="width: 100%; padding: 8px;"></textarea>
            <label for="pet_pickup">How can the animal be picked up?</label>
            <select name="pet_pickup" id="pet_pickup" required style="width: 100%; padding: 8px;">
                <option value="Pickup">Pickup</option>
                <option value="Delivery">Delivery</option>
            </select>
            <label for="owner_name">Your Name</label>
            <input type="text" name="owner_name" id="owner_name" required style="width: 100%; padding: 8px;">
            <label for="owner_email">Email Address</label>
            <input type="email" name="owner_email" id="owner_email" required style="width: 100%; padding: 8px;">
            <label for="owner_phone">Phone</label>
            <input type="text" name="owner_phone" id="owner_phone" required style="width: 100%; padding: 8px;">
            <label for="owner_city">City</label>
            <input type="text" name="owner_city" id="owner_city" required style="width: 100%; padding: 8px;">
            <label for="owner_state">State/Province</label>
            <input type="text" name="owner_state" id="owner_state" required style="width: 100%; padding: 8px;">
            <label for="pet_images">Upload Images</label>
            <input type="file" name="pet_images[]" id="pet_images" multiple required style="width: 100%; padding: 8px;">
            <input type="hidden" name="pet_submission" value="1">
            <input type="submit" value="Submit" style="margin-top: 10px; padding: 10px; width: 100%;">
        </form>
        <?php
    }
}
get_footer();
?>

Note: This code handles form submission, sanitizes inputs, creates a new "Pet" post, and saves custom fields and uploaded images.

7. Develop the "Adopt" Page to Display Pet Listings

Create a template for displaying pet listings archive-pet.php in your child theme:

php
<?php
get_header(); ?>

<main style="padding: 20px;">
    <h1>Available Pets for Adoption</h1>
    <?php if ( have_posts() ) : ?>
        <div class="pet-listings" style="display: flex; flex-wrap: wrap;">
            <?php while ( have_posts() ) : the_post(); ?>
                <div class="pet-card" style="border: 1px solid #ccc; border-radius: 8px; margin: 10px; width: calc(33% - 20px); padding: 10px;">
                    <a href="<?php the_permalink(); ?>" style="text-decoration: none; color: inherit;">
                        <?php
                        // Display pet images
                        $images = get_post_meta( get_the_ID(), 'pet_images', true );
                        if ( ! empty( $images ) ) {
                            $image_id = $images[0];
                            echo wp_get_attachment_image( $image_id, 'medium', false, array( 'style' => 'width:100%; height:auto; border-radius: 8px;' ) );
                        }
                        ?>
                        <h2><?php echo get_post_meta( get_the_ID(), 'pet_name', true ); ?></h2>
                        <p><?php echo wp_trim_words( get_the_content(), 10, '...' ); ?></p>
                    </a>
                </div>
            <?php endwhile; ?>
        </div>
        <!-- Pagination -->
        <div class="pagination" style="text-align: center;">
            <?php echo paginate_links(); ?>
        </div>
    <?php else : ?>
        <p>No pets found.</p>
    <?php endif; ?>
</main>

<?php get_footer(); ?>

8. Display Pet Details on Single Pet Page

Create single-pet.php:

php
<?php
get_header();

if ( have_posts() ) : while ( have_posts() ) : the_post();
?>

<main style="padding: 20px;">
    <h1><?php echo get_post_meta( get_the_ID(), 'pet_name', true ); ?></h1>
    <div class="pet-gallery" style="display: flex; overflow-x: scroll;">
        <?php
        $images = get_post_meta( get_the_ID(), 'pet_images', true );
        if ( ! empty( $images ) ) {
            foreach ( $images as $image_id ) {
                echo wp_get_attachment_image( $image_id, 'medium', false, array( 'style' => 'margin-right: 10px; border-radius: 8px;' ) );
            }
        }
        ?>
    </div>
    <div class="pet-details" style="margin-top: 20px;">
        <p><strong>Description:</strong> <?php the_content(); ?></p>
        <p><strong>Type of Animal:</strong> <?php echo get_post_meta( get_the_ID(), 'pet_type', true ); ?></p>
        <p><strong>Sex:</strong> <?php echo get_post_meta( get_the_ID(), 'pet_sex', true ); ?></p>
        <p><strong>Microchip Implant:</strong> <?php echo get_post_meta( get_the_ID(), 'pet_microchip', true ); ?></p>
        <p><strong>Vaccines and Surgeries:</strong> <?php echo get_post_meta( get_the_ID(), 'pet_vaccines', true ); ?></p>
        <p><strong>Pickup Method:</strong> <?php echo get_post_meta( get_the_ID(), 'pet_pickup', true ); ?></p>
    </div>
    <?php if ( is_user_logged_in() ) : ?>
        <div class="contact-info" style="margin-top: 20px;">
            <h2>Contact Information</h2>
            <p><strong>Name:</strong> <?php echo get_post_meta( get_the_ID(), 'owner_name', true ); ?></p>
            <p><strong>Email:</strong> <?php echo get_post_meta( get_the_ID(), 'owner_email', true ); ?></p>
            <p><strong>Phone:</strong> <?php echo get_post_meta( get_the_ID(), 'owner_phone', true ); ?></p>
            <p><strong>Location:</strong> <?php echo get_post_meta( get_the_ID(), 'owner_city', true ); ?>, <?php echo get_post_meta( get_the_ID(), 'owner_state', true ); ?></p>
        </div>
    <?php else : ?>
        <p>Please <a href="<?php echo wp_login_url( get_permalink() ); ?>">log in</a> to view contact information.</p>
    <?php endif; ?>
</main>

<?php
endwhile; endif;

get_footer();
?>

9. Ensure Responsive Design and Styling

Since we're minimizing plugin use, we'll add custom CSS to our style.css file in the child theme.

a. Add Custom Styles

In style.css, add styles for:

  • Header and Navigation
  • Forms and Inputs
  • Buttons and Links
  • Pet Listings and Cards
  • Media Queries for Responsiveness

Example:

css
/* Responsive Grid for Pet Listings */
@media (max-width: 768px) {
    .pet-card {
        width: calc(50% - 20px);
    }
}
@media (max-width: 480px) {
    .pet-card {
        width: 100%;
    }
}

/* Form Styles */
input[type="text"],
input[type="email"],
input[type="password"],
select,
textarea {
    width: 100%;
    padding: 8px;
    margin-top: 5px;
    margin-bottom: 15px;
    border: 1px solid #ccc;
    border-radius: 4px;
}

/* Button Styles */
input[type="submit"],
button {
    background-color: #5A9BD5;
    color: #fff;
    border: none;
    padding: 10px;
    cursor: pointer;
    border-radius: 4px;
}

/* Header Styles */
header {
    background-color: #A8D08D;
    padding: 20px;
    text-align: center;
    position: relative;
}

/* Add additional styles as needed */

10. Additional Considerations

a. Email Functionality

Ensure that your server is configured to send emails. If not, consider using an SMTP plugin or setting up SMTP in your php.ini file.

b. Security Measures

  • Nonce Verification: Add nonces to your forms to protect against CSRF attacks.
  • Input Validation: Ensure all user inputs are sanitized and validated.
  • File Uploads: Restrict file types and sizes for uploads.

c. User Account Management

Implement pages for:

  • My Account: Display user information and options to edit profile.
  • My Liked Pets: Allow users to save favorite pets (requires additional coding for likes functionality).
  • My Offered Pets: List pets the user has submitted.

d. Pagination and Search

Implement search functionality and pagination for pet listings using WordPress's built-in functions.

e. Future Enhancements

  • Internal Messaging System: Consider implementing a messaging system between users.
  • Two-Factor Authentication: Add security features as needed.
  • Accessibility: Ensure your site is accessible to users with disabilities.

Summary

By using custom code and WordPress's core functionalities, we've minimized the reliance on plugins while implementing the primary webpages and features you requested:

  • Custom User Roles and Capabilities
  • Custom Post Type for Pets
  • Custom Fields Without Plugins
  • Custom Registration and Login Forms
  • Home, Rehome, and Adopt Pages
  • Responsive Design and Styling

Next Steps

  1. Implement the provided code in your child theme.
  2. Test each feature thoroughly to ensure it works as expected.
  3. Customize styles and layouts to match your desired aesthetic.
  4. Enhance security by adding nonces and input validation where necessary.
  5. Consider adding features like user likes, messaging, and enhanced search as future improvements.

Feel free to ask if you need clarification on any part of the code or further assistance with implementation. I'm here to help you bring your website vision to life!

2/2
You said:
is it possible to edit the php directly from wordpress? if so, how? If not, do I have to put all the updates directly into the php file on my local drive, and then reupload the .zip file each time? Also, is it possible to get rid of Astra as a parent theme entirely, and begin coding this as the parent theme with no child themes yet implemented?

Great questions! I'll address each of them and provide guidance on how to proceed.

1. Is it possible to edit the PHP files directly from WordPress? If so, how?

Yes, you can edit PHP files directly from the WordPress admin dashboard using the built-in Theme Editor.

How to Edit PHP Files via the WordPress Admin Dashboard

  1. Log in to Your WordPress Admin Dashboard

    • Navigate to https://yourdomain.com/wp-admin/ and log in with your administrator credentials.

  2. Access the Theme Editor

    • In the left-hand menu, go to Appearance > Theme Editor.

  3. Select the Theme to Edit

    • If you have multiple themes installed, you can select the theme you want to edit from the dropdown at the top labeled "Select theme to edit:".
    • By default, it will open the active theme, which should be your child theme if you've set one up.

  4. Edit Theme Files

    • On the right side, you'll see a list of theme files organized by template and functionality.
    • Click on the PHP file you wish to edit (e.g., functions.php, header.php, page-home.php).

  5. Make Changes

    • The code editor allows you to edit the contents of the file.
    • Caution: The editor provides basic functionality but lacks advanced features like syntax highlighting or error checking.

  6. Save Changes

    • After making your changes, click the "Update File" button below the editor to save the file.

Important Considerations

  • Risk of Site Errors

    • Syntax Errors: If you introduce a syntax error (e.g., missing a semicolon, unmatched brackets), it can cause a PHP fatal error and bring down your site.
    • White Screen of Death: This manifests as a blank white screen on your site, making it inaccessible from both the front end and the admin dashboard.

  • Limited Features

    • The built-in editor doesn't provide advanced code editing features.
    • No automatic backups or version control.

Recommendations

  • Backup Before Editing

    • Always make a backup of the file you're editing before making changes.
    • You can copy the code and save it in a text file on your local machine.

  • Use a Development Environment

    • For extensive changes, consider setting up a local development environment using tools like Local by Flywheel, XAMPP, or MAMP.
    • Test your changes locally before applying them to your live site.

  • Alternative Editors

    • Use a code editor like Visual Studio Code or Sublime Text for better coding experience.

2. If not, do I have to put all the updates directly into the PHP files on my local drive and then reupload the .zip file each time?

You don't need to reupload the entire .zip file each time. Instead, you can upload individual files directly to your server using an SFTP client.

Using SFTP to Upload Files

  1. Install an SFTP Client

    • FileZilla: Download Here
    • Cyberduck: Download Here

  2. Connect to Your Server

    • Host: Your domain name or server IP.
    • Username and Password: Provided by your hosting provider.
    • Port: Typically 22 for SFTP.

  3. Navigate to Your Theme Directory

    • Remote Site: /wp-content/themes/your-theme-name/
    • This is where your theme files are located.

  4. Upload Files

    • Drag and drop the PHP files from your local machine to the server directory.
    • Overwrite the existing files when prompted.

  5. Set File Permissions

    • Ensure the uploaded files have the correct permissions (usually 644 for files).

Benefits of Using SFTP

  • Efficiency

    • Upload only the files you've changed, saving time.

  • Safety

    • Reduces the risk of overwriting unintended files.

  • Convenience

    • Allows you to use your preferred code editor locally.

Recommendations

  • Develop Locally

    • Make changes on your local machine where you can test them.

  • Test Before Uploading

    • If possible, test your changes on a staging site or local environment.

  • Version Control

    • Consider using Git for version control to track changes and roll back if necessary.

3. Is it possible to get rid of Astra as a parent theme entirely and begin coding this as the parent theme with no child themes yet implemented?

Yes, you can create your own custom theme from scratch, eliminating the need for a parent theme like Astra.

Creating a Custom Theme Without a Parent Theme

By creating your own theme, you have complete control over every aspect of your site's design and functionality.

Steps to Create a Custom Theme

  1. Create a New Theme Directory

    • Using SFTP or your hosting control panel's file manager, navigate to /wp-content/themes/.
    • Create a new folder for your theme, e.g., tailsadoption.

  2. Create the Required Files

    • At a minimum, your theme needs the following files:

      • style.css
      • index.php

    • Create style.css

      css
      /*
 Theme Name: Tails Adoption Theme
 Theme URI: https://tailsadoption.org/
 Description: Custom theme for Tails Adoption
 Author: Ian
 Author URI: https://tailsadoption.org/
 Version: 1.0.0
*/

    • Create index.php

      php
      <?php
// Silence is golden.
?>

    • Note: index.php is required but can be minimal initially.

  3. Add Additional Template Files

    • functions.php: For enqueuing styles and adding theme support.

      php
      <?php
function tailsadoption_setup() {
    // Add theme support features
    add_theme_support( 'title-tag' );
    add_theme_support( 'post-thumbnails' );
}
add_action( 'after_setup_theme', 'tailsadoption_setup' );

function tailsadoption_enqueue_styles() {
    wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-style', get_stylesheet_uri() );
}
add_action( 'wp_enqueue_scripts', 'tailsadoption_enqueue_styles' );
?>

    • header.php: Contains the HTML <head> section and site header.

      php
      <!DOCTYPE html>
<html <?php language_attributes(); ?>>
<head>
    <meta charset="<?php bloginfo( 'charset' ); ?>">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <?php wp_head(); ?>
</head>
<body <?php body_class(); ?>>
    <header>
        <!-- Site header content -->
    </header>

    • footer.php: Contains the site footer and closing HTML tags.

      php
          <footer>
        <!-- Site footer content -->
    </footer>
    <?php wp_footer(); ?>
</body>
</html>

    • page.php: Template for pages.

      php
      <?php get_header(); ?>
<main>
    <?php
    if ( have_posts() ) {
        while ( have_posts() ) {
            the_post();
            the_content();
        }
    }
    ?>
</main>
<?php get_footer(); ?>

    • single.php: Template for single posts.

    • archive.php: Template for archive pages.

  4. Activate Your Custom Theme

    • In your WordPress admin dashboard, go to Appearance > Themes.
    • You should see Tails Adoption Theme listed.
    • Click Activate.

  5. Develop Your Theme

    • Build out your theme templates and styles according to your site's needs.
    • Use the code and instructions provided earlier to implement features like custom post types, custom fields, and templates.

Benefits of Creating a Custom Theme

  • Full Control

    • You decide exactly how your theme functions and looks.

  • No Unnecessary Code

    • Your theme contains only the code you need, potentially improving performance.

  • Learning Opportunity

    • Deepens your understanding of WordPress theme development.

Considerations

  • Time and Effort

    • Building a theme from scratch requires more time and expertise.

  • Maintenance

    • You're responsible for maintaining the theme and ensuring compatibility with WordPress updates.

  • Support

    • Unlike established themes, you won't have community support or updates from theme developers.

Recommendations

  • Start Simple

    • Begin with basic templates and gradually add complexity.

  • Follow WordPress Standards

    • Adhere to WordPress Theme Development Standards.

  • Use Starter Themes (Optional)

    • Consider using a minimal starter theme like _s (Underscores) to kickstart development.

      • Underscores: Underscores Theme

Additional Tips

1. Use a Child Theme vs. Custom Theme

  • Child Theme

    • Pros:
      • Leverages an existing parent theme's functionality and styling.
      • Faster to set up.
    • Cons:
      • Limited by the parent theme's structure.

  • Custom Theme

    • Pros:
      • Full control over design and functionality.
    • Cons:
      • Requires more development time and expertise.

2. Set Up a Local Development Environment

  • Benefits

    • Develop and test your theme without affecting the live site.
    • Faster development cycle.

  • Tools

    • Local by Flywheel: Download Here
    • XAMPP: Download Here
    • MAMP: Download Here

3. Version Control with Git

  • Advantages

    • Track changes to your codebase.
    • Roll back to previous versions if needed.

  • Using Git

    • Initialize a Git repository in your theme directory.
    • Commit changes as you develop.

4. Testing and Debugging

  • Enable Debugging

    • In wp-config.php, set WP_DEBUG to true during development.

      php
      define( 'WP_DEBUG', true );

  • Error Logging

    • Monitor the debug log for errors and warnings.

5. Security Best Practices

  • Sanitize and Validate Inputs

    • Always sanitize user inputs and outputs.

  • Escape Outputs

    • Use escaping functions like esc_html(), esc_url(), etc.

  • Nonces

    • Use nonces for form submissions to protect against CSRF attacks.

Conclusion

  • Editing PHP Files

    • You can edit PHP files directly from the WordPress admin dashboard via the Theme Editor, but caution is advised due to potential risks.

  • Updating Theme Files

    • Using SFTP to upload individual files is more efficient than reuploading a .zip file each time.

  • Creating a Custom Theme

    • Building your own theme from scratch gives you complete control and eliminates dependency on parent themes like Astra.

Next Steps:

  1. Decide on Your Development Approach

    • If you prefer full control and are comfortable with theme development, proceed with creating a custom theme.
    • If you prefer to leverage existing structures, continue with a child theme.

  2. Set Up a Local Development Environment

    • This allows safe development and testing before deploying changes to your live site.

  3. Begin Development

    • Start building out your theme's templates and functionalities based on the requirements.

  4. Regularly Backup

    • Keep backups of your site and theme files to prevent data loss.

  5. Ask for Help When Needed

    • If you encounter challenges, don't hesitate to seek assistance from the WordPress community or professional developers.

Feel free to let me know if you need further guidance on any of these steps or have additional questions. I'm here to assist you throughout your development journey!

You said:
answer in very short: since I switched hosting to siteground, and also changed my WordPress password, would the name for "host", "username", and/or "password" be different now? if so, what would they be?

Yes, since you switched to SiteGround, your FTP/SFTP "host," "username," and "password" are different now. Your WordPress password change doesn't affect these credentials.

To find your new FTP/SFTP details:

  1. Log in to your SiteGround account.
  2. Navigate to Site Tools for your website.
  3. Go to Site > FTP Accounts.
  4. Here, you'll see your FTP hostname, and you can view or create FTP usernames and passwords.

Use these credentials to connect to your site via FTP/SFTP.

You said:
I wasn't able to edit my PHP via wordpress, as it was telling me that is not an option with my theme as it currently is. instead, I navigated to the file via FileZilla using the SFTP client with the information: host: "ftp.tailsadoption.org", username: "ianjalford@tailsadoption.org", port: "21". I am also moving away from the folder that is a child folder of the astra theme, and I am now creating all of the php files to develop my own theme in a folder within the "themes" folder titled "tailsadoption". I want you to provide all the code to get this theme started. Make it as similar to the WordPress public theme "bark". If you would find it useful to have the code from much of these files in the "bark" theme, let me know, and I will provide as much as possible. otherwise, provide the files and code to save as you know it.

Understood! Since you're creating your own custom theme named "tailsadoption", I'd be happy to help you get started. While I can't provide code from the "bark" theme due to copyright restrictions, I can guide you through building a theme with similar functionality and design elements using your own code.

Getting Started with Your Custom WordPress Theme

A basic WordPress theme requires at least two files:

  1. style.css – Contains theme metadata and custom CSS styles.
  2. index.php – The main template file.

However, to create a fully functional theme, you'll need additional template files.

1. Theme Structure

Create a new folder named tailsadoption inside your wp-content/themes/ directory. Your theme will consist of the following files:

  • style.css
  • functions.php
  • index.php
  • header.php
  • footer.php
  • sidebar.php (optional)
  • page.php
  • single.php
  • archive.php
  • comments.php (optional)
  • 404.php (optional)
  • Additional template files as needed (e.g., page-home.php, page-rehome.php)

2. Create style.css

This file contains theme information and is used to enqueue your theme's stylesheet.

css
/*
 Theme Name: Tails Adoption Theme
 Theme URI: https://tailsadoption.org/
 Description: Custom theme for Tails Adoption
 Author: Your Name
 Author URI: https://tailsadoption.org/
 Version: 1.0.0
 License: GNU General Public License v2 or later
 License URI: https://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-2.0.html
 Text Domain: tailsadoption
*/

3. Create functions.php

This file is used to set up your theme's features and enqueue scripts and styles.

php
<?php
// Theme setup
function tailsadoption_setup() {
    // Make theme available for translation
    load_theme_textdomain( 'tailsadoption', get_template_directory() . '/languages' );

    // Add default posts and comments RSS feed links to head
    add_theme_support( 'automatic-feed-links' );

    // Let WordPress manage the document title
    add_theme_support( 'title-tag' );

    // Enable support for Post Thumbnails on posts and pages
    add_theme_support( 'post-thumbnails' );

    // Register navigation menus
    register_nav_menus( array(
        'primary' => __( 'Primary Menu', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'footer'  => __( 'Footer Menu', 'tailsadoption' ),
    ) );

    // Switch default core markup for search form, comment form, etc., to output valid HTML5
    add_theme_support( 'html5', array(
        'search-form',
        'comment-form',
        'gallery',
        'caption',
    ) );
}
add_action( 'after_setup_theme', 'tailsadoption_setup' );

// Enqueue scripts and styles
function tailsadoption_scripts() {
    wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-style', get_stylesheet_uri() );
    // Enqueue additional styles or scripts here
}
add_action( 'wp_enqueue_scripts', 'tailsadoption_scripts' );
?>

4. Create index.php

This is the main template file that displays your posts.

php
<?php get_header(); ?>

<main>
    <?php if ( have_posts() ) : ?>
        <section class="post-list">
            <?php while ( have_posts() ) : the_post(); ?>
                <article id="post-<?php the_ID(); ?>" <?php post_class(); ?>>
                    <h2><a href="<?php the_permalink(); ?>"><?php the_title(); ?></a></h2>
                    <div class="entry">
                        <?php the_excerpt(); ?>
                    </div>
                </article>
            <?php endwhile; ?>
            <!-- Pagination -->
            <div class="pagination">
                <?php
                echo paginate_links( array(
                    'prev_text' => __( '&laquo; Previous', 'tailsadoption' ),
                    'next_text' => __( 'Next &raquo;', 'tailsadoption' ),
                ) );
                ?>
            </div>
        </section>
    <?php else : ?>
        <p><?php _e( 'No posts found.', 'tailsadoption' ); ?></p>
    <?php endif; ?>
</main>

<?php get_sidebar(); ?>
<?php get_footer(); ?>

5. Create header.php

This file contains the opening HTML tags and site header.

php
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html <?php language_attributes(); ?>>
<head>
    <meta charset="<?php bloginfo( 'charset' ); ?>">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
    <?php wp_head(); ?>
</head>

<body <?php body_class(); ?>>
<header>
    <div class="site-header">
        <div class="site-branding">
            <?php if ( has_custom_logo() ) : ?>
                <?php the_custom_logo(); ?>
            <?php else : ?>
                <a href="<?php echo esc_url( home_url( '/' ) ); ?>">
                    <h1><?php bloginfo( 'name' ); ?></h1>
                </a>
            <?php endif; ?>
        </div>
        <nav class="main-navigation">
            <?php
            wp_nav_menu( array(
                'theme_location' => 'primary',
                'menu_class'     => 'primary-menu',
            ) );
            ?>
        </nav>
    </div>
</header>

6. Create footer.php

This file contains the site footer and closing HTML tags.

php
<footer>
    <div class="site-footer">
        <p>&copy; <?php echo date( 'Y' ); ?> Tails Adoption. All rights reserved.</p>
        <nav class="footer-navigation">
            <?php
            wp_nav_menu( array(
                'theme_location' => 'footer',
                'menu_class'     => 'footer-menu',
            ) );
            ?>
        </nav>
    </div>
</footer>

<?php wp_footer(); ?>
</body>
</html>

7. Create sidebar.php (Optional)

If you plan to have a sidebar, include this file.

php
<aside class="sidebar">
    <?php if ( is_active_sidebar( 'main-sidebar' ) ) : ?>
        <?php dynamic_sidebar( 'main-sidebar' ); ?>
    <?php else : ?>
        <p><?php _e( 'Add widgets to the sidebar in your WordPress admin.', 'tailsadoption' ); ?></p>
    <?php endif; ?>
</aside>

Register the Sidebar in functions.php:

php
// Register sidebar
function tailsadoption_widgets_init() {
    register_sidebar( array(
        'name'          => __( 'Main Sidebar', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'id'            => 'main-sidebar',
        'description'   => __( 'Widgets in this area will be shown on all posts and pages.', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'before_widget' => '<div id="%1$s" class="widget %2$s">',
        'after_widget'  => '</div>',
        'before_title'  => '<h3 class="widget-title">',
        'after_title'   => '</h3>',
    ) );
}
add_action( 'widgets_init', 'tailsadoption_widgets_init' );

8. Create page.php

This template is used for all pages.

php
<?php get_header(); ?>

<main>
    <?php if ( have_posts() ) : while ( have_posts() ) : the_post(); ?>
        <article id="page-<?php the_ID(); ?>" <?php post_class(); ?>>
            <h1><?php the_title(); ?></h1>
            <div class="page-content">
                <?php the_content(); ?>
            </div>
        </article>
    <?php endwhile; else : ?>
        <p><?php _e( 'Sorry, no pages matched your criteria.', 'tailsadoption' ); ?></p>
    <?php endif; ?>
</main>

<?php get_sidebar(); ?>
<?php get_footer(); ?>

9. Create single.php

This template is used for single blog posts.

php
<?php get_header(); ?>

<main>
    <?php if ( have_posts() ) : while ( have_posts() ) : the_post(); ?>
        <article id="post-<?php the_ID(); ?>" <?php post_class(); ?>>
            <h1><?php the_title(); ?></h1>
            <div class="post-meta">
                <span><?php echo get_the_date(); ?></span> | 
                <span><?php the_author(); ?></span>
            </div>
            <div class="post-content">
                <?php the_content(); ?>
            </div>
            <?php comments_template(); ?>
        </article>
    <?php endwhile; else : ?>
        <p><?php _e( 'Sorry, no posts matched your criteria.', 'tailsadoption' ); ?></p>
    <?php endif; ?>
</main>

<?php get_sidebar(); ?>
<?php get_footer(); ?>

10. Create archive.php

This template displays archive pages (categories, tags, authors).

php
<?php get_header(); ?>

<main>
    <h1><?php the_archive_title(); ?></h1>
    <?php if ( have_posts() ) : ?>
        <section class="post-list">
            <?php while ( have_posts() ) : the_post(); ?>
                <article id="post-<?php the_ID(); ?>" <?php post_class(); ?>>
                    <h2><a href="<?php the_permalink(); ?>"><?php the_title(); ?></a></h2>
                    <div class="entry">
                        <?php the_excerpt(); ?>
                    </div>
                </article>
            <?php endwhile; ?>
            <!-- Pagination -->
            <div class="pagination">
                <?php
                echo paginate_links();
                ?>
            </div>
        </section>
    <?php else : ?>
        <p><?php _e( 'No posts found.', 'tailsadoption' ); ?></p>
    <?php endif; ?>
</main>

<?php get_sidebar(); ?>
<?php get_footer(); ?>

11. Create comments.php (Optional)

If you want to include comments on your posts.

php
<?php
if ( post_password_required() ) {
    return;
}

if ( have_comments() ) : ?>
    <h2><?php printf( _n( 'One comment', '%1$s comments', get_comments_number(), 'tailsadoption' ), number_format_i18n( get_comments_number() ) ); ?></h2>
    <ol class="comment-list">
        <?php
        wp_list_comments( array(
            'style' => 'ol',
            'short_ping' => true,
        ) );
        ?>
    </ol>
<?php endif; ?>

<?php comment_form(); ?>

12. Create 404.php (Optional)

Handles 404 errors.

php
<?php get_header(); ?>

<main>
    <h1><?php _e( 'Page Not Found', 'tailsadoption' ); ?></h1>
    <p><?php _e( 'Sorry, but the page you were trying to view does not exist.', 'tailsadoption' ); ?></p>
</main>

<?php get_footer(); ?>

13. Custom Page Templates

For specialized pages like "Home", "Adopt", "Rehome", create custom templates.

Example: page-home.php

php
<?php
/**
 * Template Name: Home Page
 */

get_header(); ?>

<main>
    <!-- Hero Section -->
    <section class="hero">
        <h1>Welcome to Tails Adoption</h1>
        <p>Your journey to adopting a pet starts here.</p>
        <a href="<?php echo site_url( '/adopt' ); ?>" class="button">Find a Pet</a>
    </section>

    <!-- Featured Pets -->
    <section class="featured-pets">
        <h2>Featured Pets</h2>
        <?php
        $featured_pets = new WP_Query( array(
            'post_type'      => 'pet',
            'posts_per_page' => 3,
            'meta_key'       => 'featured',
            'meta_value'     => 'yes',
        ) );

        if ( $featured_pets->have_posts() ) : ?>
            <div class="pet-list">
                <?php while ( $featured_pets->have_posts() ) : $featured_pets->the_post(); ?>
                    <div class="pet-item">
                        <a href="<?php the_permalink(); ?>">
                            <?php if ( has_post_thumbnail() ) {
                                the_post_thumbnail( 'medium' );
                            } ?>
                            <h3><?php the_title(); ?></h3>
                        </a>
                    </div>
                <?php endwhile; ?>
            </div>
        <?php else : ?>
            <p><?php _e( 'No featured pets available at the moment.', 'tailsadoption' ); ?></p>
        <?php endif; wp_reset_postdata(); ?>
    </section>

    <!-- Other Sections -->
    <!-- Add more sections as needed -->
</main>

<?php get_footer(); ?>

14. Styling Your Theme

Add CSS styles to your style.css file to define the appearance of your site.

css
/* Basic Reset */
* {
