  background-color: #4682B4; /* Darker shade of primary color */
}

/* About Us Section */
.about-us {
  padding: 80px 0;
  background-color: #f0f8ff;
}

.about-us .container {
  display: flex;
  align-items: center;
  flex-wrap: wrap;
}

.about-us .text {
  flex: 1;
  padding: 20px;
}

.about-us .text h2 {
  font-family: var(--font-primary);
  font-size: 36px;
  margin-bottom: 20px;
}

.about-us .text p {
  font-size: 18px;
  margin-bottom: 20px;
}

.about-us .text .btn {
  background-color: var(--primary-color);
  color: #fff;
  padding: 10px 25px;
  text-decoration: none;
  border-radius: 5px;
  font-size: 16px;
}

.about-us .text .btn:hover {
  background-color: #4682B4;
}

.about-us .image {
  flex: 1;
  padding: 20px;
  text-align: center;
}

.about-us .image img {
  max-width: 100%;
  border-radius: 10px;
}

/* How It Works Section */
.how-it-works {
  padding: 80px 0;
}

.how-it-works .container {
  text-align: center;
}

.how-it-works h2 {
  font-family: var(--font-primary);
  font-size: 36px;
  margin-bottom: 60px;
}

.how-it-works .steps {
  display: flex;
  justify-content: space-between;
  flex-wrap: wrap;
}

.how-it-works .step {
  flex: 1;
  min-width: 250px;
  margin: 20px;
  text-align: center;
}

.how-it-works .step h3 {
  font-size: 28px;
  margin-bottom: 15px;
}

.how-it-works .step p {
  font-size: 16px;
}

/* Featured Pets Section */
.featured-pets {
  padding: 80px 0;
  background-color: #f9f9f9;
}

.featured-pets h2 {
  font-family: var(--font-primary);
  font-size: 36px;
  text-align: center;
  margin-bottom: 60px;
}

.pet-listings {
  display: flex;
  flex-wrap: wrap;
  justify-content: center;
}

.pet-card {
  width: 300px;
  margin: 15px;
  text-align: center;
  background-color: #fff;
  padding: 15px;
  border-radius: 8px;
  box-shadow: 0 0 10px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1);
  transition: transform 0.3s ease, box-shadow 0.3s ease;
}

.pet-card:hover {
  transform: translateY(-5px);
  box-shadow: 0 10px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);
}

.pet-card img {
  width: 100%;
  height: 200px;
  object-fit: cover;
  border-radius: 8px;
}

.pet-card h2 {
  font-size: 24px;
  margin: 15px 0 10px;
}

.pet-card p {
  font-size: 16px;
  color: #666;
}

/* Contact Us Section */
.contact-us {
  padding: 80px 0;
  background-color: var(--secondary-color);
  color: #333;
}

.contact-us .container {
  max-width: 600px;
  margin: 0 auto;
  text-align: center;
}

.contact-us h2 {
  font-family: var(--font-primary);
  font-size: 36px;
  margin-bottom: 20px;
}

.contact-us p {
  font-size: 18px;
  margin-bottom: 20px;
}

.contact-us form {
  margin-top: 40px;
}

.contact-us label {
  display: block;
  text-align: left;
  margin-bottom: 5px;
  font-weight: 500;
  font-size: 16px;
}

.contact-us input,
.contact-us textarea {
  width: 100%;
  padding: 15px;
  margin-bottom: 20px;
  border: none;
  border-radius: 5px;
  font-size: 16px;
}

.contact-us input[type="submit"] {
  background-color: var(--primary-color);
  color: #fff;
  cursor: pointer;
  transition: background-color 0.3s ease;
}

.contact-us input[type="submit"]:hover {
  background-color: #4682B4;
}

/* Footer Styles */
footer {
  background-color: var(--accent-color);
  text-align: center;
  padding: 20px 0;
}

footer p {
  color: var(--text-color);
  font-size: 16px;
}

/* Animations */
@keyframes fadeInUp {
  from {
    opacity: 0;
    transform: translateY(40px);
  }
  to {
    opacity: 1;
    transform: translateY(0);
  }
}

.animate-fadeInUp {
  animation: fadeInUp 1s ease forwards;
}

.hero h1,
.hero p,
.hero .btn {
  opacity: 0;
}

.hero h1 {
  animation-delay: 0.2s;
}

.hero p {
  animation-delay: 0.4s;
}

.hero .btn {
  animation-delay: 0.6s;
}

/* Responsive Design */
@media (max-width: 768px) {
  header .container {
    flex-direction: column;
  }

  header nav ul {
    flex-direction: column;
    margin-top: 20px;
  }

  header nav ul li {
    margin-left: 0;
    margin-bottom: 10px;
  }

  .about-us .container {
    flex-direction: column;
  }

  .hero h1 {
    font-size: 48px;
  }

  .hero p {
    font-size: 20px;
  }

  .how-it-works .steps {
    flex-direction: column;
  }

  .how-it-works .step {
    margin: 20px 0;
  }

  .pet-card {
    width: 90%;
  }
}

/* Buttons */
.btn {
  background-color: var(--primary-color);
  color: #fff;
  padding: 15px 30px;
  text-decoration: none;
  border-radius: 5px;
  font-size: 18px;
  display: inline-block;
  transition: background-color 0.3s ease;
}

.btn:hover {
  background-color: #4682B4;
}

/* Links */
a {
  color: var(--primary-color);
}

a:hover {
  text-decoration: underline;
}

/* Additional Styles for "How It Works" Section */
.how-it-works .step img {
  width: 80px;
  height: 80px;
  object-fit: cover;
  margin-bottom: 20px;
  border-radius: 50%;
}

/* Contact Form Feedback */
.contact-us p {
  margin-bottom: 20px;
}

/* Form Inputs Focus State */
.contact-us input:focus,
.contact-us textarea:focus {
  outline: none;
  box-shadow: 0 0 5px var(--primary-color);
}

Instructions for Image Placement

Ensure that all images are correctly placed within your theme's images directory. Here's a guide on where to place each image and what type of image to use:

  1. Logo Image

    • File Name: logo.png
    • Folder Path: /wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/images/logo.png
    • Description: Your site's logo. Ensure it has a transparent background for better integration.

  2. Hero Background Image

    • File Name: hero-bg.jpg
    • Folder Path: /wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/images/hero-bg.jpg
    • Description: A high-quality, inspiring image of happy pets or pets with their new owners. This image will serve as the background for the hero section.

  3. About Us Image

    • File Name: about-us.jpg
    • Folder Path: /wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/images/about-us.jpg
    • Description: An image that represents your mission, such as a group of pets or a compassionate scene depicting pet adoption.

  4. Default Pet Image

    • File Name: default-pet.png
    • Folder Path: /wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/images/default-pet.png
    • Description: A placeholder image for pets that do not have a featured image. This ensures consistency in pet listings.

  5. Additional Images for "How It Works" Section (Optional)

    • File Names: step1.png, step2.png, step3.png
    • Folder Path: /wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/images/step1.png (and similarly for others)
    • Description: Icons or illustrations representing each step in the "How It Works" section.

Example:

  • To replace the hero background image, ensure that you have an image named hero-bg.jpg in the /images/ folder. The CSS already references this image:

    css
    .hero {
  background-image: url('images/hero-bg.jpg');
  /* ... other styles ... */
}

  • Similarly, place about-us.jpg in the /images/ folder to display in the About Us section.

Final Steps

  1. Upload Images to the Server:

    • Use your SFTP client (e.g., FileZilla) to navigate to /wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/images/.
    • Upload all the necessary images as outlined above.

  2. Verify Font Loading:

    • Ensure that your functions.php correctly enqueues the Google Fonts.

  3. Check Page Templates:

    • Ensure that your pages ("Home", "Adopt", "Rehome", "Donate", "Events") are correctly assigned to their respective templates.

  4. Test Animations:

    • Visit your homepage to see the fade-in animations for the hero section elements.

  5. Test the Contact Form:

    • Submit a test message through the "Contact Us" form to verify that emails are being sent correctly.

  6. Review Responsiveness:

    • Resize your browser or use developer tools to ensure the site looks good on various screen sizes (mobile, tablet, desktop).

  7. Clear Caches:

    • If you have any caching mechanisms in place, clear them to ensure the latest styles are loaded.

Additional Enhancements (Optional)

To further enhance your website's aesthetics and functionality, consider the following:

  1. Smooth Scrolling:

    • Add smooth scrolling for anchor links to improve user experience.
    css
    html {
  scroll-behavior: smooth;
}

  2. Hover Effects on Buttons and Cards:

    • Enhance interactivity with subtle hover effects.
    css
    .btn:hover {
  background-color: #4682B4;
  transform: translateY(-2px);
  box-shadow: 0 4px 6px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1);
}

.pet-card:hover {
  transform: translateY(-5px);
  box-shadow: 0 10px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);
}

  3. Typography Enhancements:

    • Improve readability with better line heights and letter spacing.
    css
    body {
  line-height: 1.8;
  letter-spacing: 0.5px;
}

h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 {
  letter-spacing: 1px;
}

  4. Button Transitions:

    • Smooth transitions for buttons.
    css
    .btn, .contact-us input[type="submit"] {
  transition: background-color 0.3s ease, transform 0.3s ease;
}

  5. Accessibility Enhancements:

    • Ensure sufficient color contrast and focus states for better accessibility.
    css
    a:focus, .btn:focus, input:focus, textarea:focus {
  outline: 2px dashed var(--primary-color);
  outline-offset: 4px;
}

Conclusion

By following the above steps and utilizing the provided style.css, your Tails Adoption Theme will have a modern, clean, and responsive design that aligns with contemporary web standards. Remember to replace the placeholder image paths (#####) with your actual image URLs as detailed in the Instructions for Image Placement section.

Feel free to further customize the styles to match your brand's unique identity and to add any additional sections or features as needed. If you encounter any issues or need further assistance, don't hesitate to reach out!

You said:
finalize and concatenate all the code for functions.php, verifying the enqueue functions, and assuming the images are in the appropriate filepath as we have been discussing.

Certainly! Below is the complete functions.php file for your Tails Adoption Theme. This file sets up the theme's core features, enqueues necessary styles and scripts, and registers the custom post type "Pet". Follow the instructions after the code block to ensure everything is set up correctly.

php
<?php
/**
 * Tails Adoption Theme functions and definitions
 *
 * @package tailsadoption
 */

/**
 * Set up theme defaults and register support for various WordPress features.
 */
function tailsadoption_setup() {
    // Make theme available for translation.
    load_theme_textdomain( 'tailsadoption', get_template_directory() . '/languages' );

    // Add default posts and comments RSS feed links to head.
    add_theme_support( 'automatic-feed-links' );

    // Let WordPress manage the document title.
    add_theme_support( 'title-tag' );

    // Enable support for Post Thumbnails on posts and pages.
    add_theme_support( 'post-thumbnails' );

    // Register navigation menus.
    register_nav_menus( array(
        'primary' => __( 'Primary Menu', 'tailsadoption' ),
    ) );

    // Switch default core markup for search form, comment form, etc., to output valid HTML5.
    add_theme_support( 'html5', array(
        'search-form',
        'comment-form',
        'gallery',
        'caption',
    ) );

    // Add support for a custom logo.
    add_theme_support( 'custom-logo', array(
        'height'      => 100,
        'width'       => 180,
        'flex-height' => true,
        'flex-width'  => true,
    ) );
}
add_action( 'after_setup_theme', 'tailsadoption_setup' );

/**
 * Enqueue scripts and styles.
 */
function tailsadoption_enqueue_styles() {
    // Enqueue main stylesheet.
    wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-style', get_stylesheet_uri() );

    // Enqueue Google Fonts.
    wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-google-fonts', 'https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Montserrat:wght@400;700&family=Roboto:wght@400;500&display=swap', false );

    // Enqueue main JavaScript file.
    wp_enqueue_script( 'tailsadoption-script', get_template_directory_uri() . '/main.js', array(), null, true );
}
add_action( 'wp_enqueue_scripts', 'tailsadoption_enqueue_styles' );

/**
 * Register Custom Post Type: Pet
 */
function tailsadoption_register_pet_cpt() {
    $labels = array(
        'name'                  => _x( 'Pets', 'Post Type General Name', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'singular_name'         => _x( 'Pet', 'Post Type Singular Name', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'menu_name'             => __( 'Pets', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'name_admin_bar'        => __( 'Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'add_new'               => __( 'Add New', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'add_new_item'          => __( 'Add New Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'new_item'              => __( 'New Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'edit_item'             => __( 'Edit Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'view_item'             => __( 'View Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'all_items'             => __( 'All Pets', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'search_items'          => __( 'Search Pets', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'parent_item_colon'     => __( 'Parent Pets:', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'not_found'             => __( 'No pets found.', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'not_found_in_trash'    => __( 'No pets found in Trash.', 'tailsadoption' ),
    );

    $args = array(
        'label'                 => __( 'Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'description'           => __( 'Pets available for adoption', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'labels'                => $labels,
        'supports'              => array( 'title', 'editor', 'thumbnail', 'custom-fields' ),
        'public'                => true,
        'has_archive'           => true,
        'hierarchical'          => false,
        'rewrite'               => array( 'slug' => 'pets' ),
        'show_in_rest'          => true, // Enables Gutenberg editor
        'menu_icon'             => 'dashicons-pets',
    );

    register_post_type( 'pet', $args );
}
add_action( 'init', 'tailsadoption_register_pet_cpt' );

?>

Instructions and Explanations

1. Theme Setup (tailsadoption_setup Function)

  • Translation Support: Makes the theme ready for translation by loading text domains.
  • Feed Links: Adds RSS feed links to the head section.
  • Title Tag: Allows WordPress to manage the document title.
  • Post Thumbnails: Enables featured images for posts and pages.
  • Navigation Menus: Registers a primary menu location for site navigation.
  • HTML5 Markup: Ensures that certain elements output valid HTML5.
  • Custom Logo: Allows the theme to support a customizable logo via the WordPress Customizer.

2. Enqueueing Styles and Scripts (tailsadoption_enqueue_styles Function)

  • Main Stylesheet: Enqueues the theme's style.css.
  • Google Fonts: Loads the Montserrat and Roboto fonts from Google Fonts. These fonts are used in your style.css for headings and body text, respectively.
  • Main JavaScript: Enqueues main.js, which handles animations and interactivity on your site.

3. Registering Custom Post Type: Pet (tailsadoption_register_pet_cpt Function)

  • Labels: Defines various labels for the "Pet" post type to appear correctly in the WordPress admin.
  • Arguments ($args):
    • Supports: Enables title, editor, thumbnail, and custom fields for the "Pet" post type.
    • Public: Makes the post type publicly queryable.
    • Has Archive: Enables an archive page for all pets.
    • Rewrite: Sets the URL slug to pets.
    • Show in REST: Enables Gutenberg editor support.
    • Menu Icon: Uses the Dashicons "pets" icon for the admin menu.

4. Image Placement

Ensure that all necessary images are placed in the /wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/images/ directory. Here are the placeholders and their corresponding image descriptions:

  1. Logo Image

    • File Name: logo.png
    • Path: /wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/images/logo.png
    • Description: Your site's logo with a transparent background.

  2. Hero Background Image

    • File Name: hero-bg.jpg
    • Path: /wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/images/hero-bg.jpg
    • Description: An inspiring image of happy pets or pets with their new owners.

  3. About Us Image

    • File Name: about-us.jpg
    • Path: /wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/images/about-us.jpg
    • Description: An image representing your mission, such as a group of pets or a compassionate scene depicting pet adoption.

  4. Default Pet Image

    • File Name: default-pet.png
    • Path: /wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/images/default-pet.png
    • Description: A placeholder image for pets that do not have a featured image.

  5. Additional Images for "How It Works" Section (Optional)

    • File Names: step1.png, step2.png, step3.png
    • Path: /wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/images/step1.png (and similarly for others)
    • Description: Icons or illustrations representing each step in the "How It Works" section.

5. Removing @import from style.css

Since you've enqueued Google Fonts via functions.php, it's best to remove any @import statements related to Google Fonts from your style.css to optimize performance.

Action:

  • Open style.css in your theme's directory.

  • Remove the following line if it exists:

    css
    @import url('https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Montserrat:wght@400;700&family=Roboto:wght@400;500&display=swap');

6. Final Checks

  1. Activate the Theme:

    • Ensure that Tails Adoption Theme is activated in Appearance > Themes.

  2. Assign Menu Locations:

    • Go to Appearance > Menus.
    • Create or select your primary menu.
    • Assign it to the Primary Menu location.

  3. Create Necessary Pages:

    • Home: Assign to the index.php (front-page) template.
    • Adopt: Assign to the page-adopt.php template.
    • Rehome: Assign to the page-rehome.php template.
    • Donate & Events: Create these pages and add them to your primary menu.

  4. Test the Site:

    • Visit https://tailsadoption.org/ to ensure the homepage displays correctly with the new styles and animations.
    • Navigate through all primary pages to verify their appearance and functionality.

  5. Check Responsiveness:

    • Ensure the site looks good on various devices (desktop, tablet, mobile).

  6. Verify Animations:

    • Ensure that the hero section elements animate as intended on page load.

  7. Test Forms:

    • Submit a test message through the "Contact Us" form to confirm email functionality.
    • Submit a test pet listing through the "Rehome" form to verify post creation.

7. Additional Recommendations

  • Backup Your Site: Before making further changes, ensure you have a recent backup of your website.
  • Use a Child Theme (If Not Already): If you plan to make extensive customizations, consider using a child theme to prevent losing changes during theme updates.
  • Optimize Images: Ensure all images are optimized for web to enhance site performance.
  • Security: Regularly update WordPress, themes, and plugins to maintain security.

Congratulations! Your functions.php is now fully set up to handle the theme's styles, scripts, and custom post types. With the provided CSS and JavaScript files in place, your website should have a modern, responsive, and engaging design that aligns with contemporary web standards.

If you encounter any issues or need further assistance with specific functionalities or design elements, feel free to reach out!

You said:
I uploaded the files without double-checking for bugs, and WordPress informed me that there was one in the functions.php causing a fatal error. So, I fixed the bug and updated the file. Still, after I corrected the bug, wordpress isn't cooperating. My theme isn't appearing on the "My Themes" page, and when I click "Install new theme", I get a webpage with the message "There has been a critical error on this website. Please check your site admin email inbox for instructions." Let's go through a detailed troubleshooting, starting with Wordpress dashboard, then with ensuring no errors in our fully concatenated codes.

I'm sorry to hear you're experiencing critical errors with your custom Tails Adoption Theme. Let's work through this step-by-step to restore your website's functionality and ensure your theme is correctly set up.

1. Accessing Your Server via FTP/SFTP

Since your site is experiencing a critical error, you'll need to access your server directly to make necessary changes.

  1. Open Your FTP Client:

    • Use FileZilla (as you've been using) or any other FTP/SFTP client.

  2. Connect to Your Server:

    • Host: ftp.tailsadoption.org (as per your previous message)
    • Username: ianjalford@tailsadoption.org
    • Password: (Your updated password)
    • Port: 21 (if using FTP) or 22 (if using SFTP)

  3. Navigate to the Themes Directory:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-content/themes/

2. Disabling the Broken Theme

To regain access to your WordPress dashboard, you need to deactivate the faulty theme.

2.1. Rename the Theme Folder

  1. Locate the Theme Folder:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/

  2. Rename the Folder:

    • Change tailsadoption to something like tailsadoption-disabled.

    Why?

    • Renaming the theme folder forces WordPress to deactivate it and revert to a default theme (e.g., Twenty Twenty-One) if available.

2.2. Confirm Theme Deactivation

  1. Access Your Website:

    • Visit https://tailsadoption.org/
    • It should now display using a default WordPress theme.

  2. Access WordPress Dashboard:

    • Navigate to https://tailsadoption.org/wp-admin/
    • Log in with your credentials.

3. Troubleshooting the Critical Error

Now that the site is accessible via a default theme, let's identify and fix the issue in your custom theme.

3.1. Enable Debugging in WordPress

  1. Access wp-config.php:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-config.php

  2. Edit the File:

    • Open wp-config.php in a text editor via your FTP client.

  3. Enable Debugging:

    • Locate the line that says define( 'WP_DEBUG', false );
    • Change it to:
      php
      define( 'WP_DEBUG', true );
define( 'WP_DEBUG_LOG', true );
define( 'WP_DEBUG_DISPLAY', false );
    • Explanation:
      • WP_DEBUG: Enables debugging mode.
      • WP_DEBUG_LOG: Saves errors to a debug.log file.
      • WP_DEBUG_DISPLAY: Prevents errors from displaying on the site, enhancing security.

  4. Save and Upload:

    • Save changes and ensure wp-config.php is uploaded back to the server.

3.2. Reproduce the Error to Generate Logs

  1. Attempt to Activate the Custom Theme:

    • Go to Appearance > Themes in the WordPress dashboard.
    • Try activating Tails Adoption Theme.

  2. Check the Error Log:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-content/debug.log
    • Download and open debug.log to review the error details.

3.3. Analyze the Error Log

Common Errors to Look For:

  • Syntax Errors:

    • Missing semicolons (;)
    • Unclosed brackets ({, }, (, ))
    • Incorrect PHP tags (<?php, ?>)

  • Functionality Errors:

    • Undefined functions or variables.
    • Issues with wp_enqueue_style or wp_enqueue_script.

Example Error Message:

go
PHP Parse error:  syntax error, unexpected '}' in /public_html/wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/functions.php on line 123

Action:

  • Identify the Line Number: Locate the problematic line in functions.php.
  • Correct the Syntax or Logic: Fix the error as indicated.

4. Verifying and Correcting functions.php

Let's ensure your functions.php is error-free.

4.1. Complete functions.php Code

Ensure your functions.php matches the following code. This version includes necessary functions and enqueues styles/scripts correctly.

php
<?php
/**
 * Tails Adoption Theme functions and definitions
 *
 * @package tailsadoption
 */

/**
 * Set up theme defaults and register support for various WordPress features.
 */
function tailsadoption_setup() {
    // Make theme available for translation.
    load_theme_textdomain( 'tailsadoption', get_template_directory() . '/languages' );

    // Add default posts and comments RSS feed links to head.
    add_theme_support( 'automatic-feed-links' );

    // Let WordPress manage the document title.
    add_theme_support( 'title-tag' );

    // Enable support for Post Thumbnails on posts and pages.
    add_theme_support( 'post-thumbnails' );

    // Register navigation menus.
    register_nav_menus( array(
        'primary' => __( 'Primary Menu', 'tailsadoption' ),
    ) );

    // Switch default core markup for search form, comment form, etc., to output valid HTML5.
    add_theme_support( 'html5', array(
        'search-form',
        'comment-form',
        'gallery',
        'caption',
    ) );

    // Add support for a custom logo.
    add_theme_support( 'custom-logo', array(
        'height'      => 100,
        'width'       => 180,
        'flex-height' => true,
        'flex-width'  => true,
    ) );
}
add_action( 'after_setup_theme', 'tailsadoption_setup' );

/**
 * Enqueue scripts and styles.
 */
function tailsadoption_enqueue_styles() {
    // Enqueue main stylesheet.
    wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-style', get_stylesheet_uri() );

    // Enqueue Google Fonts.
    wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-google-fonts', 'https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Montserrat:wght@400;700&family=Roboto:wght@400;500&display=swap', false );

    // Enqueue main JavaScript file.
    wp_enqueue_script( 'tailsadoption-script', get_template_directory_uri() . '/main.js', array(), null, true );
}
add_action( 'wp_enqueue_scripts', 'tailsadoption_enqueue_styles' );

/**
 * Register Custom Post Type: Pet
 */
function tailsadoption_register_pet_cpt() {
    $labels = array(
        'name'                  => _x( 'Pets', 'Post Type General Name', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'singular_name'         => _x( 'Pet', 'Post Type Singular Name', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'menu_name'             => __( 'Pets', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'name_admin_bar'        => __( 'Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'add_new'               => __( 'Add New', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'add_new_item'          => __( 'Add New Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'new_item'              => __( 'New Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'edit_item'             => __( 'Edit Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'view_item'             => __( 'View Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'all_items'             => __( 'All Pets', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'search_items'          => __( 'Search Pets', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'parent_item_colon'     => __( 'Parent Pets:', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'not_found'             => __( 'No pets found.', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'not_found_in_trash'    => __( 'No pets found in Trash.', 'tailsadoption' ),
    );

    $args = array(
        'label'                 => __( 'Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'description'           => __( 'Pets available for adoption', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'labels'                => $labels,
        'supports'              => array( 'title', 'editor', 'thumbnail', 'custom-fields' ),
        'public'                => true,
        'has_archive'           => true,
        'hierarchical'          => false,
        'rewrite'               => array( 'slug' => 'pets' ),
        'show_in_rest'          => true, // Enables Gutenberg editor
        'menu_icon'             => 'dashicons-pets',
    );

    register_post_type( 'pet', $args );
}
add_action( 'init', 'tailsadoption_register_pet_cpt' );

?>

4.2. Common Mistakes to Avoid

  • PHP Tags: Ensure all PHP blocks start with <?php and end with ?> if necessary.
  • Semicolons: Each statement should end with a semicolon (;).
  • Function Hooks: Ensure add_action hooks are correctly specified.
  • Nested Functions: Avoid defining functions within other functions unless intentional.
  • Closing Brackets: Ensure all { have corresponding }.

4.3. Validate the Code

  1. Use an IDE or Code Editor:

    • Visual Studio Code, Sublime Text, or Atom can help identify syntax errors.
    • Install PHP linters or use plugins to highlight errors.

  2. Check for Common Errors:

    • Missing semicolons.
    • Unclosed brackets.
    • Incorrect function names.

  3. Example Correction:

    Error:

    php
    wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-style', get_stylesheet_uri()

    Fix:

    php
    wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-style', get_stylesheet_uri() );

5. Re-uploading the Corrected functions.php

After ensuring your functions.php is error-free:

  1. Save the Corrected File:

    • Ensure there are no syntax errors.

  2. Upload via FTP:

    • Navigate to /public_html/wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/.
    • Upload the corrected functions.php, overwriting the existing one.

6. Reactivating Your Custom Theme

Now that functions.php is fixed:

  1. Rename the Theme Folder Back:

    • If you renamed it to tailsadoption-disabled, change it back to tailsadoption.

  2. Activate the Theme:

    • Go to Appearance > Themes in the WordPress dashboard.
    • Tails Adoption Theme should now appear without errors.
    • Click Activate.

  3. Verify Theme Activation:

    • Visit https://tailsadoption.org/ to see if the theme displays correctly.

7. Verifying Theme Files and Template Hierarchy

Ensure all necessary theme files are present and correctly named.

7.1. Essential Theme Files

Your theme folder /public_html/wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/ should contain:

  • style.css
  • functions.php
  • index.php (formerly front-page.php)
  • header.php
  • footer.php
  • page-adopt.php
  • page-rehome.php
  • single-pet.php
  • 404.php
  • main.js
  • images/ folder with:
    • logo.png
    • hero-bg.jpg
    • about-us.jpg
    • default-pet.png
    • (Any additional images)

7.2. Template Hierarchy

  • Home Page: index.php (if front-page.php was renamed)
  • Adopt Page: page-adopt.php (ensure the page is assigned this template)
  • Rehome Page: page-rehome.php (ensure the page is assigned this template)
  • Single Pet Page: single-pet.php (for individual pet listings)

7.3. Assigning Page Templates

  1. Go to Pages > All Pages:

    • Ensure that the Adopt and Rehome pages are assigned to their respective templates.

  2. Edit Each Page:

    • Adopt Page:
      • Click Edit.
      • In the Page Attributes box, select Adopt Page from the Template dropdown.
      • Update the page.
    • Rehome Page:
      • Click Edit.
      • In the Page Attributes box, select Rehome Page from the Template dropdown.
      • Update the page.

8. Checking for Remaining Errors

If you still encounter issues after reactivating the theme, perform the following checks:

8.1. Review the debug.log File

  1. Access debug.log:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-content/debug.log
    • Download and open the file to review any new error messages.

  2. Identify and Fix Errors:

    • Address any errors mentioned in the log by correcting the relevant files.

8.2. Verify JavaScript Files

Ensure that main.js is correctly enqueued and doesn't contain syntax errors.

  1. Check main.js:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/main.js
    • Ensure the JavaScript code is free of syntax errors.

  2. Sample main.js Code:

    javascript
    // main.js

document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function() {
  // Add animation classes to hero elements
  const heroElements = document.querySelectorAll('.hero h1, .hero p, .hero .btn');
  heroElements.forEach(function(element) {
    element.classList.add('animate-fadeInUp');
  });

  // Additional JavaScript for interactivity can be added here
});

  3. Upload Any Changes:

    • If you make changes, upload the updated main.js via FTP.

8.3. Clear Caches

If you have any caching mechanisms (server-side or via plugins), clear them to ensure you're seeing the latest changes.

9. Finalizing the Theme

Once the critical error is resolved and your theme is active:

  1. Deactivate Debugging:

    • Reopen wp-config.php.
    • Change:
      php
      define( 'WP_DEBUG', true );
define( 'WP_DEBUG_LOG', true );
define( 'WP_DEBUG_DISPLAY', false );
      To:
      php
      define( 'WP_DEBUG', false );
define( 'WP_DEBUG_LOG', false );
define( 'WP_DEBUG_DISPLAY', false );
    • Explanation:
      • Disables debugging to prevent error messages from displaying to visitors.

  2. Save and Upload:

    • Save wp-config.php and upload it back to the server.

  3. Test Your Site:

    • Visit https://tailsadoption.org/ and navigate through all primary pages to ensure they display correctly.

  4. Check Responsive Design:

    • Test the site on various devices and screen sizes.

  5. Verify Animations and Interactivity:

    • Ensure that animations on the home page are functioning as intended.

  6. Submit Forms:

    • Test the Contact Us form to verify that emails are being sent.
    • Test the Rehome form to ensure pet listings are being created correctly.

10. Summary of Key Points

  • Access via FTP/SFTP: Essential for direct file management when facing critical errors.
  • Disable Broken Theme: Renaming the theme folder forces WordPress to revert to a default theme.
  • Enable Debugging: Helps identify the exact cause of errors via debug.log.
  • Ensure Correct functions.php Code: Avoid syntax errors and ensure all functions are properly closed.
  • Reactivate Theme: Once errors are fixed, rename the theme folder back and activate it.
  • Assign Page Templates: Ensure pages use the correct custom templates.
  • Review and Correct Errors: Use debug.log to find and fix any remaining issues.
  • Finalize and Test: Disable debugging, clear caches, and thoroughly test the site.

Additional Resources

  • WordPress Theme Handbook: Theme Development
  • WordPress Codex: Function Reference
  • PHP Syntax Checker: Use online tools like PHP Code Checker to validate your PHP code.
  • Debugging Guides:
    • WordPress Debugging
    • Understanding the WordPress Template Hierarchy

Need Further Assistance?

If after following these steps you're still encountering issues:

  1. Provide Specific Error Messages:

    • Share the contents of your debug.log related to the error.

  2. Review Recent Changes:

    • List any recent edits or additions to theme files.

  3. Seek Professional Help:

    • Consider reaching out to a professional WordPress developer or support service.

I'm here to help! Please let me know if you need further guidance or encounter specific errors during this troubleshooting process.

You said:
here is my debug log: """ [06-Oct-2024 20:50:42 UTC] PHP Parse error: syntax error, unexpected token "," in /home/customer/www/tailsadoption.org/public_html/wp-content/themes/tailsadoption-disabled/functions.php on line 67 [06-Oct-2024 20:50:47 UTC] PHP Parse error: syntax error, unexpected token "," in /home/customer/www/tailsadoption.org/public_html/wp-content/themes/tailsadoption-disabled/functions.php on line 67 [06-Oct-2024 20:50:47 UTC] PHP Parse error: syntax error, unexpected token "," in /home/customer/www/tailsadoption.org/public_html/wp-content/themes/tailsadoption-disabled/functions.php on line 67 """ Here is my php code, please fix it based on what this debug is saying: """ <?php /** * Tails Adoption Theme functions and definitions * * @package tailsadoption */ /** * Set up theme defaults and register support for various WordPress features. */ function tailsadoption_setup() { // Make theme available for translation. load_theme_textdomain( 'tailsadoption', get_template_directory() . '/languages' ); // Add default posts and comments RSS feed links to head. add_theme_support( 'automatic-feed-links' ); // Let WordPress manage the document title. add_theme_support( 'title-tag' ); // Enable support for Post Thumbnails on posts and pages. add_theme_support( 'post-thumbnails' ); // Register navigation menus. register_nav_menus( array( 'primary' => __( 'Primary Menu', 'tailsadoption' ), ) ); // Switch default core markup for search form, comment form, etc., to output valid HTML5. add_theme_support( 'html5', array( 'search-form', 'comment-form', 'gallery', 'caption', ) ); // Add support for a custom logo. add_theme_support( 'custom-logo', array( 'height' => 100, 'width' => 180, 'flex-height' => true, 'flex-width' => true, ) ); } add_action( 'after_setup_theme', 'tailsadoption_setup' ); /** * Enqueue scripts and styles. */ function tailsadoption_enqueue_styles() { // Enqueue main stylesheet. wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-style', get_stylesheet_uri() ); // Enqueue Google Fonts. wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-google-fonts', 'https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Montserrat:wght@400;700&family=Roboto:wght@400;500&display=swap', false ); // Enqueue main JavaScript file. wp_enqueue_script( 'tailsadoption-script', get_template_directory_uri() . '/main.js', array(), null, true ); } add_action( 'wp_enqueue_scripts', 'tailsadoption_enqueue_styles' ); /** * Register Custom Post Type: Pet */ function tailsadoption_register_pet_cpt() { $labels = array( 'name' => ( 'Pets', 'Post Type General Name', 'tailsadoption' ), 'singular_name' => ( 'Pet', 'Post Type Singular Name', 'tailsadoption' ), 'menu_name' => ( 'Pets', 'tailsadoption' ), 'name_admin_bar' => ( 'Pet', 'tailsadoption' ), 'add_new' => ( 'Add New', 'tailsadoption' ), 'add_new_item' => ( 'Add New Pet', 'tailsadoption' ), 'new_item' => ( 'New Pet', 'tailsadoption' ), 'edit_item' => ( 'Edit Pet', 'tailsadoption' ), 'view_item' => ( 'View Pet', 'tailsadoption' ), 'all_items' => ( 'All Pets', 'tailsadoption' ), 'search_items' => ( 'Search Pets', 'tailsadoption' ), 'parent_item_colon' => ( 'Parent Pets:', 'tailsadoption' ), 'not_found' => ( 'No pets found.', 'tailsadoption' ), 'not_found_in_trash' => ( 'No pets found in Trash.', 'tailsadoption' ), ); $args = array( 'label' => ( 'Pet', 'tailsadoption' ), 'description' => ( 'Pets available for adoption', 'tailsadoption' ), 'labels' => $labels, 'supports' => array( 'title', 'editor', 'thumbnail', 'custom-fields' ), 'public' => true, 'has_archive' => true, 'hierarchical' => false, 'rewrite' => array( 'slug' => 'pets' ), 'show_in_rest' => true, // Enables Gutenberg editor 'menu_icon' => 'dashicons-pets', ); register_post_type( 'pet', $args ); } add_action( 'init', 'tailsadoption_register_pet_cpt' ); ?> """

I'm sorry to hear you're encountering issues with your custom Tails Adoption Theme. The error log indicates a syntax error on line 67 of your functions.php file, specifically an unexpected token ,. This is typically caused by incorrect usage of PHP functions or improper syntax.

Let's address the issue step-by-step to restore your theme's functionality.

1. Identifying and Fixing the Syntax Error

1.1. Understanding the Error

Error Message:

vbnet
PHP Parse error:  syntax error, unexpected token "," in /home/customer/www/tailsadoption.org/public_html/wp-content/themes/tailsadoption-disabled/functions.php on line 67

Cause:

  • The error is caused by incorrect usage of parentheses () instead of proper translation functions like __(), _x(), etc.
  • In PHP, using parentheses without a function name leads to a syntax error, especially when separating arguments with commas.

1.2. Correcting the functions.php File

Below is the corrected version of your functions.php. The primary changes involve replacing the incorrect parentheses with appropriate WordPress translation functions.

php
<?php
/**
 * Tails Adoption Theme functions and definitions
 *
 * @package tailsadoption
 */

/**
 * Set up theme defaults and register support for various WordPress features.
 */
function tailsadoption_setup() {
    // Make theme available for translation.
    load_theme_textdomain( 'tailsadoption', get_template_directory() . '/languages' );

    // Add default posts and comments RSS feed links to head.
    add_theme_support( 'automatic-feed-links' );

    // Let WordPress manage the document title.
    add_theme_support( 'title-tag' );

    // Enable support for Post Thumbnails on posts and pages.
    add_theme_support( 'post-thumbnails' );

    // Register navigation menus.
    register_nav_menus( array(
        'primary' => __( 'Primary Menu', 'tailsadoption' ),
    ) );

    // Switch default core markup for search form, comment form, etc., to output valid HTML5.
    add_theme_support( 'html5', array(
        'search-form',
        'comment-form',
        'gallery',
        'caption',
    ) );

    // Add support for a custom logo.
    add_theme_support( 'custom-logo', array(
        'height'      => 100,
        'width'       => 180,
        'flex-height' => true,
        'flex-width'  => true,
    ) );
}
add_action( 'after_setup_theme', 'tailsadoption_setup' );

/**
 * Enqueue scripts and styles.
 */
function tailsadoption_enqueue_styles() {
    // Enqueue main stylesheet.
    wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-style', get_stylesheet_uri() );

    // Enqueue Google Fonts.
    wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-google-fonts', 'https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Montserrat:wght@400;700&family=Roboto:wght@400;500&display=swap', false );

    // Enqueue main JavaScript file.
    wp_enqueue_script( 'tailsadoption-script', get_template_directory_uri() . '/main.js', array(), null, true );
}
add_action( 'wp_enqueue_scripts', 'tailsadoption_enqueue_styles' );

/**
 * Register Custom Post Type: Pet
 */
function tailsadoption_register_pet_cpt() {
    $labels = array(
        'name'                  => _x( 'Pets', 'Post Type General Name', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'singular_name'         => _x( 'Pet', 'Post Type Singular Name', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'menu_name'             => __( 'Pets', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'name_admin_bar'        => __( 'Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'add_new'               => __( 'Add New', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'add_new_item'          => __( 'Add New Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'new_item'              => __( 'New Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'edit_item'             => __( 'Edit Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'view_item'             => __( 'View Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'all_items'             => __( 'All Pets', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'search_items'          => __( 'Search Pets', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'parent_item_colon'     => __( 'Parent Pets:', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'not_found'             => __( 'No pets found.', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'not_found_in_trash'    => __( 'No pets found in Trash.', 'tailsadoption' ),
    );

    $args = array(
        'label'                 => __( 'Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'description'           => __( 'Pets available for adoption', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'labels'                => $labels,
        'supports'              => array( 'title', 'editor', 'thumbnail', 'custom-fields' ),
        'public'                => true,
        'has_archive'           => true,
        'hierarchical'          => false,
        'rewrite'               => array( 'slug' => 'pets' ),
        'show_in_rest'          => true, // Enables Gutenberg editor
        'menu_icon'             => 'dashicons-pets',
    );

    register_post_type( 'pet', $args );
}
add_action( 'init', 'tailsadoption_register_pet_cpt' );

?>

1.3. Key Corrections Made

  1. Translation Functions:

    • Before: 'name' => ( 'Pets', 'Post Type General Name', 'tailsadoption' ),
    • After: 'name' => _x( 'Pets', 'Post Type General Name', 'tailsadoption' ),

    Replaced parentheses with the _x() function, which is appropriate for context-specific translations.

  2. Single Arguments:

    • Before: 'menu_name' => ( 'Pets', 'tailsadoption' ),
    • After: 'menu_name' => __( 'Pets', 'tailsadoption' ),

    Used __() function for straightforward translations without context.

  3. Overall Syntax:

    • Ensured all array values are correctly assigned using translation functions instead of bare parentheses.
    • Verified that all parentheses and commas are correctly placed.

1.4. Upload the Corrected functions.php

  1. Access Your Server via FTP/SFTP:

    • Use your FTP client (e.g., FileZilla) to connect to your server.

  2. Navigate to the Theme Directory:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/

  3. Backup Existing functions.php:

    • Download the current functions.php to your local machine as a backup.

  4. Upload the Corrected functions.php:

    • Replace the existing functions.php with the corrected version provided above.

2. Reactivating Your Custom Theme

After correcting the functions.php, you need to reactivate your custom theme.

2.1. Rename the Theme Folder (If Previously Disabled)

If you previously renamed your theme folder to tailsadoption-disabled, revert it back to tailsadoption.

  1. Locate the Theme Folder:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-content/themes/tailsadoption-disabled/

  2. Rename the Folder:

    • Change tailsadoption-disabled back to tailsadoption.

2.2. Activate the Theme in WordPress Dashboard

  1. Log in to Your WordPress Admin Dashboard:

    • URL: https://tailsadoption.org/wp-admin/

  2. Navigate to Appearance > Themes:

    • Click on Appearance in the left-hand menu, then Themes.

  3. Find and Activate Your Theme:

    • Locate Tails Adoption Theme.
    • Click Activate.

  4. Verify Activation:

    • After activation, visit https://tailsadoption.org/ to ensure your theme displays correctly.

3. Additional Troubleshooting Steps

If the issue persists after correcting functions.php and reactivating the theme, follow these additional steps:

3.1. Check the debug.log Again

  1. Access debug.log:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-content/debug.log
    • Download and open the file to see if there are any new error messages.

  2. Address Any New Errors:

    • If new errors appear, they will guide you to further issues in your theme files.

3.2. Verify Other Theme Files

Ensure that all other essential theme files (style.css, index.php, header.php, footer.php, etc.) are correctly coded and free of syntax errors.

Example Checks:

  • header.php: Ensure all PHP tags are correctly opened and closed.
  • index.php: Verify that it calls get_header(); and get_footer(); appropriately.
  • style.css: Ensure the header comments are correctly formatted.

3.3. Ensure Correct File Permissions

Incorrect file permissions can prevent WordPress from accessing theme files.

  1. Check Permissions via FTP:

    • Files should typically have permissions set to 644.
    • Directories should have permissions set to 755.

  2. Adjust Permissions If Necessary:

    • Use your FTP client to change permissions accordingly.

3.4. Flush Permalinks

Sometimes, permalink settings can cause issues with theme templates.

  1. Navigate to Settings > Permalinks:

    • In the WordPress dashboard, go to Settings > Permalinks.

  2. Save Changes Without Modifying:

    • Click Save Changes to flush and regenerate the permalink structure.

3.5. Clear Caches

If you have caching mechanisms (server-side or via plugins), clear them to ensure you're viewing the latest changes.

4. Final Verification

After performing the above steps, verify the following:

  1. Theme Activation:

    • Ensure Tails Adoption Theme is active and displays correctly.

  2. Homepage Display:

    • Visit https://tailsadoption.org/ to see your customized homepage with the hero section, About Us, and Contact Us sections.

  3. Page Functionality:

    • Navigate to Adopt, Rehome, Donate, and Events pages to ensure they display correctly using their respective templates.

  4. Forms Functionality:

    • Test the Contact Us form to ensure emails are sent correctly.
    • Test the Rehome form to verify that pet listings are being created without errors.

  5. Responsive Design:

    • Check your website on various devices (desktop, tablet, mobile) to ensure responsiveness.

  6. Animations:

    • Verify that animations on the homepage (hero section) are functioning as intended.

5. Additional Recommendations

5.1. Use a Child Theme

If you're making significant customizations, consider using a child theme to prevent losing changes during theme updates.

  1. Create a Child Theme Folder:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-content/themes/tailsadoption-child/

  2. Create a style.css File in the Child Theme:

    css
    /*
Theme Name: Tails Adoption Child Theme
Template: tailsadoption
*/

@import url("../tailsadoption/style.css");

/* Add any additional custom styles below */

  3. Create a functions.php File in the Child Theme:

    php
    <?php
/**
 * Tails Adoption Child Theme functions and definitions
 */

function tailsadoption_child_enqueue_styles() {
    wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-parent-style', get_template_directory_uri() . '/style.css' );
}
add_action( 'wp_enqueue_scripts', 'tailsadoption_child_enqueue_styles' );

?>

  4. Activate the Child Theme:

    • Go to Appearance > Themes and activate Tails Adoption Child Theme.

5.2. Regular Backups

Ensure you regularly back up your website to prevent data loss during such issues.

5.3. Validate HTML and CSS

Use tools like W3C Markup Validation Service and W3C CSS Validation Service to validate your site's HTML and CSS.

5.4. Optimize for Performance

Consider optimizing images, leveraging browser caching, and minimizing CSS and JavaScript to enhance site performance.

Conclusion

By correcting the syntax errors in your functions.php and following the detailed troubleshooting steps, your Tails Adoption Theme should function correctly without causing critical errors. Ensure all theme files are properly coded, uploaded, and assigned, and verify that your site settings align with your theme's structure.

If you continue to experience issues after these corrections, please share the updated debug.log entries, and I'll assist you further in resolving them.

Feel free to reach out if you need any more assistance or encounter additional issues. I'm here to help you get your website up and running smoothly!

I'm sorry to hear you're still experiencing issues with your Tails Adoption Theme. The error log indicates a syntax error on line 67 of your functions.php file due to an unexpected comma, which is typically caused by incorrect use of parentheses instead of proper translation functions.

Let's address this systematically to restore your theme's functionality.

1. Understanding the Error

Error Message:

vbnet
PHP Parse error:  syntax error, unexpected token "," in /home/customer/www/tailsadoption.org/public_html/wp-content/themes/tailsadoption-disabled/functions.php on line 67

Cause:

  • The error arises from incorrect syntax in your functions.php file. Specifically, using parentheses () instead of appropriate WordPress translation functions like __(), _x(), etc.
  • PHP interprets ( 'Pets', 'Post Type General Name', 'tailsadoption' ) as an invalid expression, leading to the unexpected comma error.

2. Correcting the functions.php File

Below is the corrected version of your functions.php file. This version replaces the incorrect parentheses with the appropriate translation functions and ensures proper syntax throughout.

2.1. Corrected functions.php

php
<?php
/**
 * Tails Adoption Theme functions and definitions
 *
 * @package tailsadoption
 */

/**
 * Set up theme defaults and register support for various WordPress features.
 */
function tailsadoption_setup() {
    // Make theme available for translation.
    load_theme_textdomain( 'tailsadoption', get_template_directory() . '/languages' );

    // Add default posts and comments RSS feed links to head.
    add_theme_support( 'automatic-feed-links' );

    // Let WordPress manage the document title.
    add_theme_support( 'title-tag' );

    // Enable support for Post Thumbnails on posts and pages.
    add_theme_support( 'post-thumbnails' );

    // Register navigation menus.
    register_nav_menus( array(
        'primary' => __( 'Primary Menu', 'tailsadoption' ),
    ) );

    // Switch default core markup for search form, comment form, etc., to output valid HTML5.
    add_theme_support( 'html5', array(
        'search-form',
        'comment-form',
        'gallery',
        'caption',
    ) );

    // Add support for a custom logo.
    add_theme_support( 'custom-logo', array(
        'height'      => 100,
        'width'       => 180,
        'flex-height' => true,
        'flex-width'  => true,
    ) );
}
add_action( 'after_setup_theme', 'tailsadoption_setup' );

/**
 * Enqueue scripts and styles.
 */
function tailsadoption_enqueue_styles() {
    // Enqueue main stylesheet.
    wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-style', get_stylesheet_uri() );

    // Enqueue Google Fonts.
    wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-google-fonts', 'https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Montserrat:wght@400;700&family=Roboto:wght@400;500&display=swap', false );

    // Enqueue main JavaScript file.
    wp_enqueue_script( 'tailsadoption-script', get_template_directory_uri() . '/main.js', array(), null, true );
}
add_action( 'wp_enqueue_scripts', 'tailsadoption_enqueue_styles' );

/**
 * Register Custom Post Type: Pet
 */
function tailsadoption_register_pet_cpt() {
    $labels = array(
        'name'                  => _x( 'Pets', 'Post Type General Name', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'singular_name'         => _x( 'Pet', 'Post Type Singular Name', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'menu_name'             => __( 'Pets', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'name_admin_bar'        => __( 'Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'add_new'               => __( 'Add New', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'add_new_item'          => __( 'Add New Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'new_item'              => __( 'New Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'edit_item'             => __( 'Edit Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'view_item'             => __( 'View Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'all_items'             => __( 'All Pets', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'search_items'          => __( 'Search Pets', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'parent_item_colon'     => __( 'Parent Pets:', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'not_found'             => __( 'No pets found.', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'not_found_in_trash'    => __( 'No pets found in Trash.', 'tailsadoption' ),
    );

    $args = array(
        'label'                 => __( 'Pet', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'description'           => __( 'Pets available for adoption', 'tailsadoption' ),
        'labels'                => $labels,
        'supports'              => array( 'title', 'editor', 'thumbnail', 'custom-fields' ),
        'public'                => true,
        'has_archive'           => true,
        'hierarchical'          => false,
        'rewrite'               => array( 'slug' => 'pets' ),
        'show_in_rest'          => true, // Enables Gutenberg editor
        'menu_icon'             => 'dashicons-pets',
    );

    register_post_type( 'pet', $args );
}
add_action( 'init', 'tailsadoption_register_pet_cpt' );

?>

2.2. Key Corrections Made

  1. Translation Functions:

    • Before: 'name' => ( 'Pets', 'Post Type General Name', 'tailsadoption' ),
    • After: 'name' => _x( 'Pets', 'Post Type General Name', 'tailsadoption' ),

    Replaced parentheses with _x() for context-specific translations.

  2. Consistent Use of __() and _x():

    • Ensured all labels and arguments use appropriate translation functions.
    • Example:
      php
      'menu_name' => __( 'Pets', 'tailsadoption' ),

  3. Syntax Integrity:

    • Ensured all array entries end with commas where necessary.
    • Verified that all parentheses and brackets are correctly opened and closed.

3. Uploading the Corrected functions.php

To resolve the syntax error and restore your theme, follow these steps:

3.1. Access Your Server via FTP/SFTP

  1. Open Your FTP Client:

    • Use FileZilla or any other FTP/SFTP client you prefer.

  2. Connect to Your Server:

    • Host: ftp.tailsadoption.org (replace with your actual FTP host if different)
    • Username: ianjalford@tailsadoption.org
    • Password: (Your updated password)
    • Port: 21 for FTP or 22 for SFTP

  3. Navigate to the Theme Directory:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-content/themes/

3.2. Rename the Broken Theme Folder (If Not Already Done)

If you haven't already, rename the problematic theme folder to disable it and revert to a default theme.

  1. Locate the Theme Folder:

    • Current Path: /public_html/wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/

  2. Rename the Folder:

    • Change tailsadoption to tailsadoption-disabled.

    Why?

    • Renaming the folder forces WordPress to deactivate the theme and switch to a default theme (e.g., Twenty Twenty-One).

3.3. Upload the Corrected functions.php

  1. Navigate to the Disabled Theme Folder:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-content/themes/tailsadoption-disabled/

  2. Backup Existing functions.php:

    • Download the current functions.php to your local machine as a backup.

  3. Upload the Corrected functions.php:

    • Replace the existing functions.php with the corrected version provided above.
    • Ensure that the upload completes successfully.

3.4. Rename the Theme Folder Back

After uploading the corrected functions.php, rename the theme folder back to enable it.

  1. Locate the Disabled Theme Folder:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-content/themes/tailsadoption-disabled/

  2. Rename the Folder:

    • Change tailsadoption-disabled back to tailsadoption.

3.5. Activate the Theme in WordPress Dashboard

  1. Log in to Your WordPress Admin Dashboard:

    • URL: https://tailsadoption.org/wp-admin/

  2. Navigate to Appearance > Themes:

    • Click on Appearance in the left-hand menu, then Themes.

  3. Find and Activate Your Theme:

    • Locate Tails Adoption Theme.
    • Click Activate.

  4. Verify Activation:

    • Visit https://tailsadoption.org/ to ensure your theme displays correctly without errors.

4. Additional Troubleshooting Steps (If Needed)

If the issue persists after following the above steps, proceed with the following additional troubleshooting measures.

4.1. Re-enable Debugging Temporarily

If the error remains, re-enable debugging to capture any new error messages.

  1. Access wp-config.php:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-config.php

  2. Edit the File:

    • Open wp-config.php in a text editor via your FTP client.

  3. Enable Debugging:

    • Locate the line:
      php
      define( 'WP_DEBUG', false );
    • Change it to:
      php
      define( 'WP_DEBUG', true );
define( 'WP_DEBUG_LOG', true );
define( 'WP_DEBUG_DISPLAY', false );
    • Explanation:
      • WP_DEBUG: Enables debugging mode.
      • WP_DEBUG_LOG: Saves errors to a debug.log file.
      • WP_DEBUG_DISPLAY: Prevents errors from displaying on the site, enhancing security.

  4. Save and Upload:

    • Save changes and ensure wp-config.php is uploaded back to the server.

4.2. Check the debug.log File Again

  1. Access debug.log:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-content/debug.log
    • Download and open the file to review any new error messages.

  2. Identify and Fix Errors:

    • Address any errors mentioned in the log by correcting the relevant files.

4.3. Verify Other Theme Files

Ensure that all other essential theme files are correctly coded and free of syntax errors.

  • header.php: Ensure all PHP tags are correctly opened and closed.
  • index.php: Verify that it calls get_header(); and get_footer(); appropriately.
  • style.css: Ensure the header comments are correctly formatted.

4.4. Validate JavaScript Files

Ensure that main.js is correctly enqueued and doesn't contain syntax errors.

  1. Check main.js:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/main.js
    • Ensure the JavaScript code is free of syntax errors.

  2. Sample main.js Code:

    javascript
    // main.js

document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function() {
  // Add animation classes to hero elements
  const heroElements = document.querySelectorAll('.hero h1, .hero p, .hero .btn');
  heroElements.forEach(function(element) {
    element.classList.add('animate-fadeInUp');
  });

  // Additional JavaScript for interactivity can be added here
});

  3. Upload Any Changes:

    • If you make changes, upload the updated main.js via FTP.

4.5. Flush Permalinks

Sometimes, permalink settings can cause issues with theme templates.

  1. Navigate to Settings > Permalinks:

    • In the WordPress dashboard, go to Settings > Permalinks.

  2. Save Changes Without Modifying:

    • Click Save Changes to flush and regenerate the permalink structure.

4.6. Check File Permissions

Incorrect file permissions can prevent WordPress from accessing theme files.

  1. Check Permissions via FTP:

    • Files should typically have permissions set to 644.
    • Directories should have permissions set to 755.

  2. Adjust Permissions If Necessary:

    • Use your FTP client to change permissions accordingly.

4.7. Clear Caches

If you have any caching mechanisms (server-side or via plugins), clear them to ensure you're viewing the latest changes.

5. Final Verification

After performing the corrections and troubleshooting steps, verify the following:

  1. Theme Activation:

    • Ensure Tails Adoption Theme is active and displays correctly.

  2. Homepage Display:

    • Visit https://tailsadoption.org/ to see your customized homepage with the hero section, About Us, and Contact Us sections.

  3. Page Functionality:

    • Navigate to Adopt, Rehome, Donate, and Events pages to ensure they display correctly using their respective templates.

  4. Forms Functionality:

    • Contact Us Form: Submit a test message to confirm email functionality.
    • Rehome Form: Submit a test pet listing to verify post creation without errors.

  5. Responsive Design:

    • Check your website on various devices (desktop, tablet, mobile) to ensure responsiveness.

  6. Animations:

    • Verify that animations on the homepage (hero section) are functioning as intended.

6. Additional Recommendations

6.1. Use a Child Theme (If Not Already)

If you're making significant customizations, consider using a child theme to prevent losing changes during theme updates.

  1. Create a Child Theme Folder:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-content/themes/tailsadoption-child/

  2. Create a style.css File in the Child Theme:

    css
    /*
Theme Name: Tails Adoption Child Theme
Template: tailsadoption
*/

@import url("../tailsadoption/style.css");

/* Add any additional custom styles below */

  3. Create a functions.php File in the Child Theme:

    php
    <?php
/**
 * Tails Adoption Child Theme functions and definitions
 */

function tailsadoption_child_enqueue_styles() {
    wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-parent-style', get_template_directory_uri() . '/style.css' );
}
add_action( 'wp_enqueue_scripts', 'tailsadoption_child_enqueue_styles' );
?>

  4. Activate the Child Theme:

    • Go to Appearance > Themes and activate Tails Adoption Child Theme.

6.2. Regular Backups

Ensure you regularly back up your website to prevent data loss during such issues.

6.3. Validate HTML and CSS

Use tools like W3C Markup Validation Service and W3C CSS Validation Service to validate your site's HTML and CSS.

6.4. Optimize for Performance

Consider optimizing images, leveraging browser caching, and minimizing CSS and JavaScript to enhance site performance.

Conclusion

By replacing the incorrect parentheses with appropriate translation functions and ensuring proper syntax throughout your functions.php file, you should resolve the syntax error causing the critical issue. Follow the outlined steps carefully to upload the corrected file, reactivate your theme, and verify that your website functions as intended.

If you encounter any further errors, please share the updated debug.log entries, and I'll assist you further in resolving them.

Feel free to reach out if you need any more assistance or encounter additional issues. I'm here to help you get your website up and running smoothly!

You said:
in short, does any of my code utilize an API? What is an API, anyway? Is it coded with a specific language?

Understanding APIs and Their Role in Your Code

1. What is an API?

API stands for Application Programming Interface. It's a set of rules and protocols that allows different software applications to communicate with each other. Think of an API as a bridge that enables two separate systems to interact without needing to know the internal workings of each other.

Key Points:

  • Facilitates Communication: APIs allow applications to request and exchange data seamlessly.
  • Abstracts Complexity: They hide the complex implementation details, providing a simple interface for developers.
  • Widely Used: APIs are fundamental in web development, enabling integrations with third-party services, databases, and more.

Real-World Analogy: Imagine you're at a restaurant. The menu represents the API, listing all the dishes (services) you can order. You (the client) place an order (request) through the waiter (API), who then communicates with the kitchen (server) to prepare your meal and bring it back to you.

2. Does Your Code Utilize an API?

Based on the functions.php code you've provided, here's how APIs come into play:

  1. WordPress Functions and Hooks:

    • Internal API: WordPress offers a robust set of functions, hooks, and filters that themes and plugins use to interact with the core system. While not external APIs, they function similarly by providing standardized ways to extend and customize WordPress.
    • Examples in Your Code:
      • add_theme_support()
      • register_nav_menus()
      • wp_enqueue_style()
      • wp_enqueue_script()
      • register_post_type()

  2. Google Fonts:

    • External API Usage: By enqueuing Google Fonts in your functions.php, you're indirectly utilizing Google's Fonts API. This API allows your website to fetch and display fonts hosted by Google.
    • Example in Your Code:
      php
      wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-google-fonts', 'https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Montserrat:wght@400;700&family=Roboto:wght@400;500&display=swap', false );

  3. Contact Forms and Email Functionality:

    • WordPress Email Functions: When handling form submissions (like your "Contact Us" form), you're using WordPress's email functions (wp_mail()) to send emails. While this isn't an external API, it's an interface provided by WordPress to interact with email services.

Summary:

  • Internal APIs: Your theme extensively uses WordPress's internal APIs to register features, enqueue styles/scripts, and define custom post types.
  • External APIs: Minimal direct use, primarily through integrating Google Fonts.

3. What Languages are APIs Coded With?

APIs themselves aren't bound to a single programming language. Instead, the language used depends on the platform and the purpose of the API. Here's a breakdown:

  1. Web APIs:

    • Languages Used: Typically built using languages like PHP, JavaScript, Python, Ruby, Java, or Go.
    • Example: The Google Fonts API is a web API that responds to HTTP requests, regardless of the client's language.

  2. Library or Framework APIs:

    • Languages Used: Dependent on the library/framework.
    • Example: WordPress's internal functions are written in PHP since WordPress is a PHP-based platform.

  3. Operating System APIs:

    • Languages Used: Often written in C or C++ for performance reasons.
    • Example: Windows API for interacting with the Windows operating system.

  4. Database APIs:

    • Languages Used: Varies; commonly SQL for querying, but interfaces can be in PHP, Python, etc.
    • Example: MySQL's API allows applications to interact with the MySQL database.

Key Takeaways:

  • Flexibility: APIs can be implemented in virtually any programming language.
  • Interoperability: The primary goal of an API is to enable communication between different systems, regardless of the languages they're built with.

4. How APIs are Used in Your Development Workflow

Given your work with WordPress and custom themes:

  • Leveraging WordPress APIs: You're utilizing WordPress's internal APIs to enhance and customize your theme's functionality. This includes registering custom post types, adding theme supports, and managing scripts/styles.

  • Integrating Third-Party APIs: By enqueuing Google Fonts, you're integrating an external API to enhance your site's typography without hosting the fonts yourself.

Benefits of Using APIs:

  • Efficiency: Save time by leveraging existing functionalities instead of building from scratch.
  • Scalability: Easily integrate new features and services as your website grows.
  • Maintainability: APIs provide standardized methods to implement features, making your code cleaner and easier to manage.

5. Practical Example: Using WordPress's REST API

While not directly in your current code, understanding the WordPress REST API can be beneficial:

  • What It Is: A set of endpoints that allow external applications to interact with your WordPress site by performing actions like fetching posts, creating new content, updating user information, etc.

  • Usage Scenario: Suppose you want to build a mobile app for Tails Adoption. You can use the WordPress REST API to fetch pet listings, handle user authentication, and submit adoption forms directly from the app.

  • How to Access:

    • Endpoint Example: https://tailsadoption.org/wp-json/wp/v2/pets
    • Fetch Pets: You can perform GET requests to retrieve pet data.

Sample JavaScript Fetch Request:

javascript
fetch('https://tailsadoption.org/wp-json/wp/v2/pets')
  .then(response => response.json())
  .then(data => {
    console.log(data); // Handle pet data
  })
  .catch(error => console.error('Error:', error));

Benefits:

  • Separation of Concerns: Decouple your front-end (e.g., a mobile app) from your WordPress back-end.
  • Flexibility: Integrate with various platforms and services seamlessly.

6. Conclusion

  • APIs are Integral: Whether internal (like WordPress's functions) or external (like Google Fonts), APIs play a crucial role in modern web development by enabling seamless interactions and integrations.

  • Your Code's API Usage: Your current functions.php leverages both WordPress's internal APIs and an external API (Google Fonts) to build a feature-rich and well-designed theme.

  • Languages are Flexible: APIs can be built and interacted with using various programming languages, ensuring versatility and broad compatibility across different systems and platforms.

If you have more questions about APIs or need assistance integrating specific APIs into your WordPress theme, feel free to ask!

You said:
5 words what does react and node.js code for

Frontend interfaces and server-side applications.

You said:
some parts of my code don't seem to be functioning, including full CSS, javascript, and the queueings. provide a checklist with detailed steps to check every box so that I can navigate wordpress and ensure all settings are aligned to allow all current plugins to operate appropriately with our code, and then provide what debugging steps I should take upon our code assuming the wordpress checklist failed to solve the issues

I'm sorry to hear you're continuing to experience issues with your Tails Adoption Theme. Let's tackle this systematically to identify and resolve the problems affecting your CSS, JavaScript, and enqueueing processes.

Comprehensive Troubleshooting Checklist for Your WordPress Theme

1. WordPress Dashboard Settings

1.1. Theme Activation

  • Verify Active Theme:
    • Navigate to Appearance > Themes.
    • Ensure Tails Adoption Theme is active.
    • If not, activate it. If it's not visible, confirm the theme folder is correctly named and located in /wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/.

1.2. Menu Assignments

  • Check Menus:
    • Go to Appearance > Menus.
    • Ensure that your primary menu includes all necessary links (Home, Adopt, Rehome, Donate, Events, etc.).
    • Assign the menu to the Primary Menu location.

1.3. Page Template Assignments

  • Assign Correct Templates:
    • Navigate to Pages > All Pages.
    • Edit each page (Home, Adopt, Rehome, Donate, Events).
    • In the Page Attributes box, ensure the correct template is selected (e.g., Adopt Page, Rehome Page).
    • Update the pages after confirming.

1.4. Permalink Settings

  • Flush Permalinks:
    • Go to Settings > Permalinks.
    • Without making changes, click Save Changes to flush and regenerate the permalink structure.

1.5. Reading Settings

  • Homepage Configuration:
    • Navigate to Settings > Reading.
    • Ensure Your homepage displays is set appropriately:
      • Your latest posts: Uses front-page.php or index.php.
      • A static page: Assign the Home page to display your custom homepage template.
    • Save any changes if necessary.

1.6. Site URL and Home URL

  • Verify URLs:
    • Go to Settings > General.
    • Ensure WordPress Address (URL) and Site Address (URL) are correctly set to https://tailsadoption.org.
    • Correct any discrepancies and save changes.

2. Theme File Structure and Placement

2.1. Verify Theme Files Location

  • Check Directory Structure:
    • Ensure all theme files are directly within /wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/.
    • Essential Files:
      • style.css
      • functions.php
      • index.php
      • header.php
      • footer.php
      • page-adopt.php
      • page-rehome.php
      • single-pet.php
      • 404.php
      • main.js
      • images/ folder with necessary images (logo.png, hero-bg.jpg, about-us.jpg, etc.).

2.2. Ensure Correct File Naming

  • File Names:
    • Templates should be named correctly, e.g., page-adopt.php for the Adopt page.
    • Avoid typos or incorrect casing in file names.

2.3. Image Paths

  • Verify Image Paths in Code:
    • Ensure all image URLs in your theme files point to the correct locations, e.g., images/hero-bg.jpg.
    • Example:
      css
      .hero {
  background-image: url('images/hero-bg.jpg');
}
    • Confirm that the images exist in /wp-content/themes/tailsadoption/images/.

3. Enqueueing Styles and Scripts

3.1. Verify functions.php Enqueue Functions

  • Check for Correct Syntax:
    • Ensure all wp_enqueue_style and wp_enqueue_script functions are correctly formatted.
    • Example:
      php
      function tailsadoption_enqueue_styles() {
    wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-style', get_stylesheet_uri() );
    wp_enqueue_style( 'tailsadoption-google-fonts', 'https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Montserrat:wght@400;700&family=Roboto:wght@400;500&display=swap', false );
    wp_enqueue_script( 'tailsadoption-script', get_template_directory_uri() . '/main.js', array(), null, true );
}
add_action( 'wp_enqueue_scripts', 'tailsadoption_enqueue_styles' );
  • Check for Dependencies:
    • Ensure scripts and styles have correct dependencies and versions if necessary.
  • No Duplicate Enqueues:
    • Avoid enqueuing the same script or style multiple times.

3.2. Verify main.js Functionality

  • Check JavaScript Syntax:
    • Ensure main.js is free of syntax errors.
    • Example:
      javascript
      document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function() {
  const heroElements = document.querySelectorAll('.hero h1, .hero p, .hero .btn');
  heroElements.forEach(function(element) {
    element.classList.add('animate-fadeInUp');
  });
});
  • Console Errors:
    • Open your website in a browser.
    • Press F12 to open developer tools and check the Console for JavaScript errors.

4. Plugin Compatibility and Conflicts

4.1. Review Active Plugins

  • Check Plugins:
    • Go to Plugins > Installed Plugins.
    • Note all active plugins, especially those related to themes, page builders, caching, or security.

4.2. Disable All Plugins Temporarily

  • Test Theme Without Plugins:
    • Deactivate all plugins.
    • Check if the theme functions correctly.
    • If it does, reactivate plugins one by one to identify the conflicting plugin.

4.3. Update Plugins and WordPress Core

  • Ensure Everything is Updated:
    • Update all plugins to their latest versions.
    • Update WordPress to the latest version if not already.

4.4. Check for Plugin Conflicts

  • Identify Conflicts:
    • If a specific plugin causes issues upon activation, consider:
      • Checking for updates or support from the plugin developer.
      • Finding an alternative plugin with similar functionality.
      • Customizing your theme to avoid the conflict.

5. Caching and Performance

5.1. Clear Browser Cache

  • Refresh Your Browser:
    • Hold Shift and click the refresh button or use Ctrl + F5 to perform a hard refresh.

5.2. Clear Server-Side Cache

  • If Using Caching Plugins:
    • Clear caches via the plugin settings (e.g., W3 Total Cache, WP Super Cache).
  • Hosting Provider Caching:
    • Some hosts have built-in caching; clear it via your hosting dashboard if available.

6. File Permissions and Server Configuration

6.1. Check File Permissions

  • Standard Permissions:
    • Files: 644
    • Directories: 755
  • Adjust via FTP:
    • Use your FTP client to set correct permissions.

6.2. PHP Version Compatibility

  • Ensure Compatibility:
    • Verify your server is running a compatible PHP version (preferably PHP 7.4 or higher).
    • Check with your hosting provider if unsure.

6.3. Server Error Logs

  • Review Server Logs:
    • Access your hosting control panel or use FTP to find error logs.
    • Look for any server-side issues beyond WordPress's debug log.

7. Debugging Steps if Checklist Fails

If after completing the above checklist the issues persist, proceed with these detailed debugging steps:

7.1. Enable WordPress Debugging

  1. Access wp-config.php:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-config.php

  2. Edit the File:

    • Open wp-config.php in a text editor via your FTP client.

  3. Enable Debugging:

    • Locate the line:
      php
      define( 'WP_DEBUG', false );
    • Change it to:
      php
      define( 'WP_DEBUG', true );
define( 'WP_DEBUG_LOG', true );
define( 'WP_DEBUG_DISPLAY', false );
    • Explanation:
      • WP_DEBUG: Enables debugging mode.
      • WP_DEBUG_LOG: Saves errors to a debug.log file located in /wp-content/.
      • WP_DEBUG_DISPLAY: Prevents errors from displaying on the site, enhancing security.

  4. Save and Upload:

    • Save changes and upload wp-config.php back to the server.

7.2. Reproduce the Error and Review debug.log

  1. Trigger the Error:

    • Attempt to activate the theme or perform actions that were previously causing issues.

  2. Access debug.log:

    • Path: /public_html/wp-content/debug.log
    • Download and open the file to review detailed error messages.

  3. Identify Specific Errors:

    • Look for errors related to your theme files, especially functions.php, style.css, and main.js.

7.3. Check Browser Console for JavaScript Errors

  1. Open Your Website:

    • Navigate to https://tailsadoption.org/.

  2. Open Developer Tools:

    • Press F12 or Ctrl + Shift + I (Windows) / Cmd + Option + I (Mac).

  3. Check the Console Tab:

    • Look for any JavaScript errors or warnings that might affect functionality.

7.4. Validate CSS and JavaScript

  1. CSS Validation:

    • Use the W3C CSS Validation Service to check your style.css for errors.
    • Upload or paste your CSS to validate.

  2. JavaScript Validation:

    • Use tools like JSHint or ESLint to validate main.js.
    • Ensure there are no syntax errors or undefined variables/functions.

7.5. Inspect Enqueued Styles and Scripts

  1. View Page Source:

    • Right-click on your webpage and select View Page Source.
    • Ensure that all CSS and JS files are correctly enqueued and linked.

  2. Check Network Requests:

    • In Developer Tools, go to the Network tab.
    • Refresh the page and verify that all CSS and JS files are loading without 404 errors.

7.6. Review functions.php for Remaining Errors

  1. Ensure Correct Syntax:

    • Confirm that all PHP functions are correctly opened and closed.
    • Verify that all array entries use proper translation functions.

  2. Sample Correct functions.php:

    • Here's the corrected version based on your previous code. Ensure it matches exactly.
      php
      <?php
/**
